explanations: The translation of "des Genies corporels" (corporeal Geniuses/spirits) as "our Faries, whom they alow to be Corporeal" alters the original. "Genies" was a broader term in 17th-century French for various spiritual or elemental beings, potentially carrying philosophical or occult connotations. "Faries" is a more specific folkloric term, and "our Faries" domesticates the concept, linking it to English/British popular belief. This substitution can subtly diminish the nature of the "folly" Fontenelle critiques, shifting it from potentially learned (though misguided) speculation to more common superstition, thereby altering the reader's perception of the belief being discussed.

The original French describes the spirits' visits as "dives of very short duration" ("des plongeons de tres-peu de durée"), a general statement of their brevity. The translation replaces this with a highly specific and culturally English comparison: "cannot stay half so long in it, as one of the worst of Sir Harry Blount's Sponge-gatherers." This addition of a contemporary English reference (Sir Henry Blount was a known English traveller) and the vivid, almost comical quantitative comparison significantly alters the tone, making the spirits (now "Faries") seem particularly inept and grounding the critique in a specific English cultural context absent from Fontenelle's more universal and philosophical original. It intensifies the mockery, manipulating the reader's perception.

Fontenelle's "Quelques Modernes" (Some Moderns) is rendered as "Some of our Modern Philosophers." While specifying "Moderns" as "Philosophers" (likely natural philosophers) is an interpretation, the addition of "our" subtly manipulates the reader's perception. It creates a sense of an intellectual in-group shared by the narrator/translator and the English reader, framing these thinkers within a familiar, possibly Anglo-centric, tradition. This contrasts with Fontenelle's more detached and universal phrasing, subtly shifting the reader's relationship to these proponents of new science.

The French "une espece de Lunette naturelle" (a kind of natural telescope/lens) is translated as "a kind of Natural Spectacles." In the 17th century, "lunette" (singular) could refer to a telescope, spyglass, or a single lens, fitting for an analogy about the atmosphere acting as a singular optical medium modifying perception. "Spectacles" (eyeglasses) specifically denotes a pair of lenses in a frame, a personal corrective device. This substitution subtly alters Fontenelle's scientific metaphor. It replaces the image of a single optical instrument or medium, potentially evoking the telescopes central to the new astronomy, with that of everyday eyeglasses. This may make the analogy more familiar but less precise for a singular atmospheric lens and loses the resonance with scientific instruments of discovery, thus shifting the reader's understanding.

Consistent with the previous instance, the translation of "cette Lunette" (this telescope/lens) as "their Spectacles" reinforces the alteration of Fontenelle's original metaphor. By consistently using "Spectacles" where Fontenelle used "Lunette" (singular), the translation shifts the reader's understanding of the optical analogy from a single intervening medium or scientific instrument to personal eyewear, subtly changing the character and connotations of the scientific explanation being popularized.

chunks.source_manual: <P045>Cela me fait préférer nostre sejour à celuy de la Lune, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, je ne saurois croire que l'assortiment des couleurs celestes y soit aussi beau qu'il l'est icy. Mettons, si vous voulez, un Ciel rouge, & des Etoiles vertes, l'effet n'est pas si agreable que des Etoiles couleur d'or sur du bleu. On diroit à vous entendre, <UP></UP>, repris-je, que vous assortiriez un habit, ou un meuble; mais, croyez-moy, la Nature a bien de l'esprit; laissez-luy le soin d'inventer un assortiment de couleurs pour la Lune, & je vous garantis qu'il sera bien entendu. Elle n'aura pas manqué de varier le Spectacle de l'Univers à chaque point de veüe diferent <UP></UP>, & de le varier d'une maniere toûjours agreable.</P045> <P046>Je reconnois son adresse, interrompit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, elle s'est épargné la peine de changer les objets pour chaque point de veüe, elle n'a changé que les Lunettes, & elle a l'honneur de cette grande diversité, sans en avoir fait la dépense. Avec un air bleu, elle nous donne un Ciel bleu, & peut-estre avec un Air rouge, elle donne un Ciel rouge aux Habitans de la Lune, c'est pourtant toûjours le mesme Ciel. Il me paroist qu'elle nous a mis aussi dans l'imagination certaines Lunettes, au travers desquelles on voit tout, & qui changent fort les objets à l'égard de chaque homme. Alexandre voyoit la Terre comme une belle place bien propre à y établir un grand Empire. Celadon ne la voyoit que comme <RW>le sejour d'Astrée</RW>. Un Philosophe la voit comme une grosse Planete qui va par les Cieux, toute couverte de fous. Je ne croy pas que le Spectacle change plus de la Terre à la Lune, qu'il fait icy d'imagination à imagination.</P046>
chunks.target_manual: <P035>If it be so, said the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, I prefer my abode before that of the Moon; for I cannot believe the Celestial Colours are so well suited as they are here; for if you will let us put green Stars on a red Sky, they cannot be so agreable as Stars of Gold on an Azure Firmament. To hear you, said I, one would think you was chusing a <UP>Petticoat, or a suit of Knots; but believe me, Nature hath as good a Fancy as Mrs. Harrison</UP>; leave it to her to chuse Colours for the Moon, and I'll engage they shall be well sorted; she will not fail to vary the Prospect of the Universe, at every different point of Sight, and always the Alteration shall be very agreable. I know very well, said the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, her Skill in this Point; she is not at the charge of changing the Objects, but only the Spectacles, and hath the credit of this great variety, without being at any expence; with a blue Air, she gives us a blue Firmament; and perhaps with a red Air, she gives to the Inhabitants of the Moon a red Firmament; and yet still it is but the same Firmament; nay, I am of opinion, she hath plac'd a sort of Spectacles in our Imagination, through which we see all things, and which to every particular Man change the Objects. Alexander look'd on the Earth as a fit place to establish a great Empire, it seem'd to Celadon a proper residence for Astraea, and it appear'd to a Philosopher, a great Planet in the Heavens, covered with Fools: I do not believe the Sights vary more between the Earth and the Moon, than they do between one Man's Fancy and anothers.</P035>

un habit, ou un meuble
la Nature a bien de l'esprit
d'imagination à imagination
target_segments: said the Countess
a Petticoat, or a suit of Knots
Nature hath as good a Fancy as Mrs. Harrison
between one Man's Fancy and anothers
explanations: The change from "Marquise" (Marchioness) to "Countess" alters the specific noble rank of the female interlocutor. As a Countess is of a lower rank than a Marchioness, this subtly diminishes the character's depicted status. This is significant given Fontenelle's aim to popularize science among educated women, often of high nobility, and it can shift the reader's perception of the character's social standing and authority within the dialogue.

The original French "un habit, ou un meuble" (an outfit/dress, or a piece of furniture) provides general examples of choosing coordinated items. The translation to "a Petticoat, or a suit of Knots" (specific, fashionable feminine accessories) narrows the scope, trivializes the comparison, and reinforces gender stereotypes. This subtly manipulates the reader's perception of the Marquise's character, potentially undermining her intellectual engagement by framing her analogy in terms of minor fashion details.

The translation of "la Nature a bien de l'esprit" (Nature has great wit/intelligence/mind) to "Nature hath as good a Fancy as Mrs. Harrison" introduces two manipulations. Firstly, the intellectual and profound "esprit" is reduced to "Fancy," which can imply mere taste or caprice. Secondly, the addition of the culturally specific and contemporary English reference "Mrs. Harrison" domesticates the text while also diminishing the personification of Nature by comparing its inherent intelligence to a specific human's aesthetic sense, thereby shifting the philosophical weight of the statement.

The phrase "d'imagination à imagination" (from imagination to imagination), referring to the diverse ways individuals perceive the world, is translated as "between one Man's Fancy and anothers." Using "Fancy" instead of a more direct equivalent for the French "imagination" (which suggests a profound mental faculty) alters the connotation. In the 17th-century context, "Fancy" could imply whim, caprice, or superficial preference, potentially leading the reader to interpret these fundamental perceptual differences as less significant or less philosophically deep than Fontenelle intended.

chunks.source_manual: <P047>Le changement de Spectacle est plus surprenant dans nos imaginations, repliquay-je, car ce ne sont que les mesmes objets qu'on voit si diferemment; du moins dans la Lune on peut voir d'autres objets, ou ne pas voir quelques-uns de ceux qu'on voit icy. Peut-estre ne connoissent-ils point en ce Pays-là l'Aurore, ny les Crepuscules, avant que le Soleil se leve, ou aprés qu'il est couché. L 'Air qui nous environne, & qui est élevé au dessus de nous, reçoit des rayons qui ne pourroient pas tomber sur la Terre, & parce qu'il est fort grossier, il en arreste une partie, & nous les renvoye, quoy qu'ils ne nous fussent pas naturellement destinez. Ainsi l'Aurore & les Crepuscules sont une grace que la Nature nous fait; c'est une lumiere que régulierement nous ne devrions point avoir, & qu'elle nous donne par dessus ce qui nous est dû. Mais dans la Lune, où apparemment l'Air est plus pur, il pourroit bien n'estre pas si propre à renvoyer en bas les rayons qu'il reçoit du Soleil avant qu'il se leve, ou aprés qu'il est couché. Vous n'avez donc cette lumiere de faveur <NCP></NCP>, qui en se fortifiant peu à peu, vous prepare agreablement à l'arrivée du Soleil, ou qui en s'affoiblissant comme de nuance en nuance, vous accoûtume à sa perte. Vous estes dans des tenebres profondes <NCP></NCP>, & tout d'un coup il semble qu'on tire un rideau, voila vos yeux frapez de tout l'éclat qui est dans le Soleil; vous estes dans une lumiere vive & éclatante, & tout d'un coup vous voila tombés dans des tenebres profondes. Le jour & la nuit ne sont point liez par un milieu qui tienne de l'un & de l'autre. L'Arc-en-ciel est encore une chose qui manque aux Gens de la Lune, car si l'Aurore est un effet de la grossiereté de l'air & des vapeurs, l'Arc-en-ciel se forme dans les nuages d'où tombent les pluyes, & nous devons les plus belles choses du monde à celles qui le sont le moins. Puis <UP></UP> qu'il n'y a autour de la Lune ny vapeurs assez grossieres, ny nuages pluvieux, adieu l'Arc-en-ciel avec l'Aurore, & à quoy ressembleront les Belles de ce Pays-là? Quelle source de comparaisons perduë!</P047>
chunks.target_manual: <P036>This change in our Imaginations, said I, is very surprizing; for they are still the same Objects, tho' they appear different; when in the Moon, we may see other Objects we do not see here, or at least, not see all there we do see here; perhaps in that Country they know nothing of the Dawn and the Twilight, before the Sun riseth, and after the Sun sets; the Air which encompasseth, and is elevated above us, receives the Rays, so that they cannot strike on the Earth; and being gross, stops some of them, and sends 'em to us, tho' indeed they were never naturally design'd us; so that the Day-break and the Twilight are a favour which Nature bestows on us; they are a Light which regularly we should not have, and which she gives us over and above our due; but in the Moon, where apparently the Air is more pure, and therefore not so proper to send down the Beams it receives from the Sun before his rising, and after his setting; you have not that Light of Grace <NCP>(as I may call it)</NCP> which growing greater by degrees, doth more agreably prepare you for the arrival of the Sun, and which growing weaker, and diminishing by degrees, doth insensibly prepare you for the Sun's departure: But you are in a profound darkness, where a Curtain <NCP>(as it were)</NCP> is drawn all on a sudden, your Eyes are immediately dazled with the whole light of the Sun, in all its glory and brightness; so likewise, you are on a sudden surpriz'd with utter Darkness; the Night and the Day have no medium between them, but you fall in a moment from one extreme into the other. The Rainbow likewise is not known to them in the Moon; for if the Dawn is an effect of the grossness of the Air and Vapours, the Rainbow is form'd in the Clouds, from whence the Rain falls; so that the most beautiful things in the World, are produc'd by those things which have no beauty at all. Since then there are no Vapours thick enough, nor no Clouds of Rain about the Moon, farewell Dawn, adieu Rainbow: What must Lovers do for Similies in that Countrey, when such an inexhaustible Magazine of Comparisons is taken from them?</P036>

cette lumiere de faveur

nous devons les plus belles choses du monde à celles qui le sont le moins.
& à quoy ressembleront les Belles de ce Pays-là? Quelle source de comparaisons perduë!
target_segments: receives the Rays, so that they cannot strike on the Earth
that Light of Grace (as I may call it)
a Curtain (as it were) is drawn
so that the most beautiful things in the World, are produc'd by those things which have no beauty at all.
What must Lovers do for Similies in that Countrey, when such an inexhaustible Magazine of Comparisons is taken from them?
explanations: The French "reçoit des rayons qui ne pourroient pas tomber sur la Terre" (receives rays that would not be able to fall on Earth [at that point/directly]) describes rays whose trajectory would miss the observer but are scattered by the atmosphere. The English translation "receives the Rays, so that they cannot strike on the Earth" introduces a slightly different causal implication with "so that," suggesting the air's reception *prevents* rays from striking, rather than scattering rays that would have otherwise passed over. This subtly alters the reader's understanding of the popularised scientific explanation of twilight.

The translator's addition of the parenthetical phrase "(as I may call it)" after "Light of Grace" (for the French "cette lumiere de faveur") introduces a note of hesitancy, self-consciousness, or qualification not present in Fontenelle's more direct metaphorical expression. This subtly manipulates the reader's perception by making the metaphor seem more idiosyncratic or tentative, possibly to temper the strong religious connotations of "Grace" in 17th-century English.

Fontenelle's "il semble qu'on tire un rideau" (it seems that one draws a curtain) already indicates the metaphorical nature of the comparison. The English translation's addition of "(as it were)" further emphasizes the figurative aspect, making the image seem more deliberately constructed and less immediate than in the original. This creates a subtle distance from the vividness of the metaphor.

The French "celles qui le sont le moins" (those that are the least so [beautiful]) implies a low position on a scale of beauty. The English translation "those things which have no beauty at all" changes this to an absolute lack of beauty. This intensification creates a starker, more absolute contrast than Fontenelle's more nuanced observation, thereby subtly altering the philosophical point about beauty arising from less aesthetically pleasing sources.

The original French "& à quoy ressembleront les Belles de ce Pays-là?" (and what will the Beauties of that country be like/resemble?) playfully questions how beautiful women ("les Belles") would be perceived or described without common earthly similes. The translation shifts this focus to "What must Lovers do for Similies...", changing the subject of concern from the nature of beauty itself to the practical rhetorical difficulties of "Lovers." Furthermore, "Quelle source de comparaisons perduë!" (What a lost source of comparisons!) is transformed and amplified into "when such an inexhaustible Magazine of Comparisons is taken from them?", introducing the stronger metaphor "Magazine," the intensifier "inexhaustible," and the more active sense of deprivation ("taken from them") versus the simpler "lost." This significantly alters the tone and focus of Fontenelle's whimsical reflection.

chunks.source_manual: <P048>Je n'aurois pas grand regret à ces comparaisons là, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, & je trouve qu'on est assez bien recompensé dans la Lune <UP></UP>, de n'avoir ny Aurore ny Arc-en- ciel, car on ne doit avoir par la mesme raison ny Foudres ny Tonnerres, puisque ce sont aussi des choses qui se forment dans les nüages. On a de beaux jours toûjours serains pendant lesquels on ne perd point le Soleil de veuë <NCE></NCE>. On n'a point de nuits où toutes les Etoiles ne se montrent <UP></UP>; on ne connoist ny les orages ny les tempestes, ny tout ce qui paroist estre un effet de la colere du Ciel, trouvez-vous qu'on soit tant à plaindre? Vous me faites voir la Lune comme un séjour enchanté, répondis-je; cependant je ne sçay s'il est si délicieux d'avoir toûjours sur la teste, un Soleil ardent dont aucun nüage ne modere la chaleur. Peut-estre aussi est-ce à cause de cela que la Nature a creusé dans la Lune des especes de Puits, qui sont assez grands pour estre apperceus par nos Lunettes; car ce ne sont point des Vallées qui soient entre des Montagnes, ce sont des creux que l'on voit au milieu de certains lieux plats. Que sçait-on si les Habitans de la Lune, incommodez par l'ardeur perpetuelle du Soleil, ne se refugient point dans ces grands Puits? Ils n'habitent peut-estre point ailleurs, c'est-là qu'ils bâtissent leurs Villes. Nous voyons icy que la Rome soûterraine estoit presque aussi grande que la Rome qui estoit sur Terre. Il ne faudroit qu'oster celle-cy, le reste seroit une Ville à la maniere de la Lune. Tout un Peuple est dans un Puits, & d'un Puits à l'autre il y a des chemins soûterrains pour la communication des Peuples. Vous vous mocquez de cette vision, j'y consens de tout mon cœr; cependant, à vous parler tres serieusement, vous pourriez vous tromper plûtost que moy. Vous croyez que les Gens de la Lune doivent habiter sur la surface de leur Planete, parce que nous habitons sur la surface de la nostre: c'est tout le contraire, puisque nous habitons sur la surface de nostre Planete, ils pourroient bien n'habiter pas sur la surface de la leur. D'icy là il faut que toutes choses soient bien differentes. <UP></UP></P048>
chunks.target_manual: <P037>I doubt not, said the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, but there are those in the Moon as good at Simily as <UP>the greatest Beau in Covent-Garden</UP>; and had they neither Sun nor Stars, <NCE>Pearls nor Rubies, Roses nor Lillies</NCE>, yet could say as many fine things to <UP>a Visor-Mask, as the pertest Wit at the Puppet Show</UP>; and they are well enough recompenc'd for the loss of our Dawn and Rainbow; for by the same reason, they have neither Thunder nor Lightning, both which are formed in the Clouds; how glorious are their days, the Sun continually shining? How pleasant their Nights, not the least Star is hid from them? They never hear of Storms or Tempests, which certainly are an effect of the wrath of Heaven: Do you think then they stand in need of our pity? You are describing the Moon, I reply'd, like an enchanted Palace; but do you think it is so pleasant to have a scorching Sun always over our Heads, and not the least Cloud to moderate its Heat? Tho' I fancy 'tis for this reason that Nature hath made great Cavities in the Moon; we can discern 'em easily with our Tellescopes, for they are not Mountains, but so many Wells or Vaults in the middle of a Plain; and what do we know but the Inhabitants of the Moon, being continually broil'd by the excessive heat of the Sun, do retire into those great Wells; perhaps they live no where else, and 'tis there they build 'em Cities; for we still see in the Ruines of old Rome, that that part of the City which was under ground, <UP>was almost as large as that which was above ground. I fancy, during the late siege of Buda, they liv'd there as they do in the Moon, or 'tis but going to the Fountain Tavern Cellar, where the several Vaults are as so many high Streets, the Vats, Pipes, Hogsheads, so many different Edifices, and the Drawers and Coopers, like so many Troglodites</UP>. I perceive you laugh at me, yet if I may be so free with a fair Lady, you deserve it much better than I; for you believe the People in the Moon must live upon the surface of their Planet, because we do so upon ours; but quite contrary, since we dwell upon the Superficies of our Planet, they should not dwell upon the superficies of their Planet; if things differ so much in this World, what must they do in another?</P037>

Il ne faudroit qu'oster celle-cy, le reste seroit une Ville à la maniere de la Lune. Tout un Peuple est dans un Puits, & d'un Puits à l'autre il y a des chemins soûterrains pour la communication des Peuples.
cependant, à vous parler tres serieusement, vous pourriez vous tromper plûtost que moy.
target_segments: I doubt not, said the Countess, but there are those in the Moon as good at Simily as the greatest Beau in Covent-Garden; and had they neither Sun nor Stars, Pearls nor Rubies, Roses nor Lillies, yet could say as many fine things to a Visor-Mask, as the pertest Wit at the Puppet Show;

I fancy, during the late siege of Buda, they liv'd there as they do in the Moon, or 'tis but going to the Fountain Tavern Cellar, where the several Vaults are as so many high Streets, the Vats, Pipes, Hogsheads, so many different Edifices, and the Drawers and Coopers, like so many Troglodites.
yet if I may be so free with a fair Lady, you deserve it much better than I;
explanations: The original French has the Marquise stating she would not greatly regret "those comparisons" (likely referring to earthly poetic conventions or previous topics). The English translation replaces this brief, reflective comment with an entirely new, elaborate speech attributed to the "Countess." This extensive addition introduces contemporary English cultural references (Covent Garden, Visor-Mask, Puppet Show) and a flamboyant, witty tone completely absent in Fontenelle's original. This manipulates the reader's perception by significantly altering the Marquise's character, making her sound more like a figure from English Restoration comedy, and changing the style of the dialogue from Fontenelle's elegant philosophical exchange to something more akin to contemporary English social satire.

Following the discussion of subterranean Rome (which is present in both texts as an analogy for lunar cities), the English translation inserts entirely new analogies attributed to the philosopher. These additions vividly describe life during the "late siege of Buda" (1686) and an elaborate scene in a London "Fountain Tavern Cellar," complete with specific details ("Vats, Pipes, Hogsheads," "Drawers and Coopers"). These contemporary and local English references are absent in Fontenelle's original, which confines its analogy to the more classical example of Rome. This addition manipulates the reader by altering the philosopher's voice, making it more colloquial and grounded in specific English culture of the late 17th century, thereby shifting the tone of his scientific popularization and potentially making the text more immediately engaging but less universal than the original.

The original French has the philosopher politely suggesting to the Marquise, "speaking very seriously, you might be mistaken rather than I." The English translation dramatically alters this to the harsher and more personal retort, "you deserve it much better than I" (implying she deserves to be laughed at or is more deserving of being wrong/mistaken). The added preamble "if I may be so free with a fair Lady" attempts a veneer of period-specific gallantry but the core statement is a significant shift in meaning and tone. This manipulation changes the philosopher's character from one of gentle, intellectual guidance to a more pointed, almost condescending figure, altering the reader's perception of the interpersonal dynamic in the dialogue and the philosopher's demeanor.

chunks.source_manual: <P049>Il n'importe, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, je ne puis me resoudre à laisser vivre les Habitans de la Lune dans une obscurité perpetuelle. Vous y auriez encore plus de peine, répris-je, si vous sçaviez qu'un grand Philosophe de l'Antiquité a fait de la Lune le séjour des Ames qui ont merité icy d'estre bien-heureuses. Toute leur felicité consiste en ce qu'elles y entendent l'Harmonie que les Corps Celestes font par leurs mouvemens; mais comme il pretend que quand la Lune tombe dans l'ombre de la Terre, elles ne peuvent plus entendre cette Harmonie <UP></UP>; alors, dit-il, ces Ames crient comme des desesperées, & la Lune se haste le plus qu'elle peut de les tirer d'un endroit si facheux. Nous devrions donc, repliqua-t-elle, voir arriver icy les Bienheureux de la Lune, car apparemment on nous les envoye aussi, & dans ces deux Planetes on croit avoir assez pourveu à la felicité des Ames, de les avoir transportées dans un autre Monde. Serieusement, répris-je, ce ne seroit pas un plaisir mediocre de voir plusieurs Mondes differens. Ce Voyage me réjoüit quelquefois beaucoup à ne le faire qu'en imagination, & que seroit-ce, si on le faisoit en effet? Cela vaudroit bien mieux que d'aller d'icy au Japon, c'est à dire de ramper avec beaucoup de peine d'un point de la Terre sur un autre, pour ne voir que des hommes. Eh bien, dit-elle, faisons le Voyage des Planetes, comme nous pourrons; qui nous en empesche? Allons nous placer dans tous ces differens points de veuê, & de là considerons l'Univers. N'avons-nous plus rien à voir dans la Lune? Je croy que non, répondis-je, du moins je vous y ay fait voir tout ce qui estoit de ma connoissance. Au sortir de la Lune en tirant vers le Soleil, on trouve Venus. Sur Vénus je reprens le <NCE>Saint Denis</NCE>. Venus tourne sur elle-mesme, & autour du Soleil <UP>comme la Lune</UP>, on découvre avec les <NCP><IIM>Lunettes d'approche</IIM></NCP>, que Venus aussi-bien que la Lune, est tantost en Croissant, tantost en Décours, tantost pleine selon les diverses situations où elle est à l'égard de la Terre. La Lune selon toutes les apparences est habitée, pourquoy Vénus ne le sera-t-elle pas aussi? Mais, interrompit-elle, en disant toûjours Pourquoy non, vous m'allez mettre des Habitans dans toutes les Planetes? N'en doutez pas, répliquay-je, ce Pourquoy a une vertu qui suffira pour peupler tout. Nous voyons que toutes les Planetes sont de la mesme nature, toutes des Corps <IIM>opaques</IIM> qui ne reçoivent de la lumiere que du Soleil, qui se la renvoyent les uns aux autres, & qui n'ont que les mesmes mouvemens, jusque là tout est égal. Cependant il faudroit concevoir que ces grands Corps auroient esté faits pour n'estre point habitez, que ce seroit là leur condition naturelle, & qu'il y auroit une exception justement en faveur de la Terre toute seule. Qui voudra le croire, le croye; pour moy, je ne m'y puis pas resoudre? Je vous trouve, dit-elle, bien affermy dans vôtre opinion depuis quelques instans. <UP></UP> Je viens de voir le moment que la Lune seroit deserte, & que vous ne vous en souciïez pas beaucoup, & presentement si on osoit vous dire que toutes les Planetes ne sont pas aussi habitées que la Terre, je voy bien que vous vous mettriez en colere. Il est vray, répondis-je, que dans le moment où vous venez de me surprendre, si vous m'eussiez contredit sur les Habitans des Planetes, non seulement je vous les aurois soutenus, mais je crois que je vous aurois dit comment ils estoient tous faits. Il y a des momens pour croire, & je ne les ay jamais si bien crûs que dans celuy là; mais presentement que je suis un peu plus de sens froid, je ne laisse pas de trouver qu'il seroit bien étrange que la Terre fust aussi habitée qu'elle l'est, & que les autres Planetes ne le fussent point du tout; car ne croyez pas que nous voyions tout ce qui habite la Terre; il y a autant d'especes d'Animaux invisibles que de visibles. Nous voyons depuis l'Elephant jusqu'au <UP></UP> Ciron; là finit nostre veuë; mais au Ciron commence une multitude infinie d'Animaux, dont il est l'Elephant, & que la simple veuë ne sçauroit appercevoir. On a vu avec des <RW>Lunettes</RW> beaucoup de Liqueurs toutes remplis de petits Animaux que l'on n'auroit jamais soupçonnez d'y estre, & il y a quelque apparence que le goût qu'elles font sentir, sont les piqueures que ces petits Animaux font à la langue & au palais. Meslez de certaines choses dans quelques-unes de ces Liqueurs, ou exposez-les au Soleil, ou laissez-les se corrompre, voilà aussi-tost de nouvelles especes de petits Animaux.</P049>
chunks.target_manual: <P038>'Tis no matter, said the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, I can never suffer the Inhabitants of the Moon to live in perpetual darkness. You will be more concern'd for 'em, I reply'd, when I tell you that one of the ancient Philosophers did long since discover the Moon to be the abode of the blessed Souls departed out of this Life, and that all their Happiness consisted in hearing the Harmony of the Spheres; <UP>that is, the Musick (I had like to have said Noise) which is made by the motion of the Celestial Bodies; if you have seen a Rar�e Show, you will easily comprehend it: But because the Philosopher pretends to know exactly all they do there, he tells you, that when the Moon is obscur'd by the shadow of the Earth, they no longer hear the Heavenly Musick, but howl like so many Souls in Purgatory</UP>; so that the Moon taking pity of 'em, makes all the haste she can to get into the Light again. Methinks then, says she, we should now and then see some of the Blessed Souls arrive here from the Moon, for certainly they are sent to us. I confess indeed, said I, it would be very pleasant to see different Worlds; such a Voyage, tho' but in Imagination, is very delightful; what would it be in effect? It would be much better certainly than to go to Japan, which at best, is but crawling from one end of the World to t' other, and after all to see nothing but Men. Well then, says she, let us travel over the Planets, as fast as we can; what should hinder us? Let us place our selves at all the different Prospects, and from thence consider the Universe. But first, have we any thing more to see in the Moon? I believe not, I reply'd; at least, you have seen all I can shew you. Coming out of the Moon, towards the Sun, we see Venus, which puts me again in mind of <NCE>Greenwich</NCE>. Venus turns upon her self, and round the Sun, as well as the Moon; they likewise discover by their Tellescopes, that Venus like the Moon, <NCP>(if I may speak after the same manner)</NCP> is sometimes new, sometimes full, and sometimes in the wain, according to the diverse situations she is in, in respect of the Earth.</P038> <P039>The Moon, to all appearance, is inhabited, why should no Venus be so too? You are so full of your Whys, and your Wherefores, says she, interrupting me, that I fancy you are sending Colonies to all the Planets. You may be certain, so I will, I reply'd, for I see no reason to the contrary; we find that all the Planets are of the same nature, all <IIM>obscure</IIM> Bodies, which receive no light but from the Sun, and then send it to one another; their motions are the same, so that hitherto they are alike; and yet if we are to believe that these vast Bodies are not inhabited, I think they were made but to little purpose; why should Nature be so partial, as to except only the Earth? But let who will say the contrary, I must believe the Planets are peopled as well as the Earth. I find, says the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, with some concern, <UP>a Philosopher will never make a good Martyr</UP>, you can so quickly shift your Opinion, 'twas not many minutes since the Moon was a perfect Desart, now the rest of the Planets are inhabited. Why truly, Madam, said I, there is a time for all things, and your true Philosopher believes any thing, or nothing, <UP>as the Maggot bites</UP>. Had you taken me in the <UP>sceptical Vein</UP>, I would have as soon granted a Nation in a Mustard Ball, as a living Creature in the Moon; but the tide is turn'd, and all the Planets are Peopled like an <UP>Anthill</UP>; yet, <UP>Raillery apart</UP>, this is not so very improbable as you think it; for do you believe we discover, (as I may say) all the Inhabitants of the Earth? there be as many kinds of invisible as visible Creatures; we see from the Elephant to the very Hand-worm, beyond which our Sight fails us, and yet counting from that minute Creature, there are an infinity of lesser Animals, which were they perceptible, would be as little in comparison with a Mite, as a Mite is of an Ox. How lately have our <NCE>Virtuoso's</NCE> found out the Pepper Worms, which in the least drop of <RW>Water appear like so many Dolphins, sporting in the Ocean</RW>; nay, they tell you that the sharpness of Vinegar consists in the fierceness of the little Animals that bite you by the Tongue; not to name the blue on Plums, and twenty Experiments of the like nature.</P039>

explanations: The translator's additions '(I had like to have said Noise)' and 'if you have seen a Rar�e Show, you will easily comprehend it' introduce a skeptical and trivializing tone towards the 'Harmony of the Spheres,' altering the original's straightforward philosophical presentation and potentially undermining its seriousness.

The general 'ces Ames crient comme des desesperées' (cry out like desperate ones) is translated as 'howl like so many Souls in Purgatory.' This introduces 'Purgatory,' a specific Christian theological concept absent in the original, which could resonate controversially with a late 17th-century English Protestant audience and subtly injects a religious specificity not intended by Fontenelle.

The translation directly corresponds to 'car apparemment on nous les envoye aussi' but omits the subsequent reflective clause: '& dans ces deux Planetes on croit avoir assez pourveu à la felicité des Ames, de les avoir transportées dans un autre Monde.' (and in these two Planets, it is believed that the happiness of souls has been sufficiently provided for by transporting them to another World). This omission removes a philosophical point about differing conceptions of spiritual well-being, simplifying the Marquise's intellectual engagement.

The French idiom 'je reprens le Saint Denis,' implying getting carried away or confused, is replaced by 'puts me again in mind of Greenwich,' a reference to the English observatory. This changes the philosopher's expression of being overwhelmed by the subject of Venus to a factual, geographical association, altering his character's playful, slightly flustered tone to a more observational one.

The original 'mettre des Habitans' (to put inhabitants) is translated as 'sending Colonies.' This introduces the concept of colonization, which was highly relevant to 17th-century England. This subtly links the philosophical speculation to contemporary imperial practices, potentially manipulating the reader's perception of the philosopher's endeavor by framing it in terms of expansion or control.

The original notes the philosopher's shift towards strong conviction (potential anger if contradicted: 'vous vous mettriez en colere'). The translation adds the judgment 'a Philosopher will never make a good Martyr' and reinterprets his evolving stance as mere fickleness ('so quickly shift your Opinion'). This addition casts doubt on philosophical conviction itself, contrasting it negatively with religious steadfastness ('Martyr'), a potent comparison in the English religious climate of the time.

The philosopher's nuanced admission of fluctuating conviction ('Il y a des momens pour croire... presentement que je suis un peu plus de sens froid') is transformed into the derogatory 'your true Philosopher believes any thing, or nothing, as the Maggot bites.' This addition, along with colorful but unoriginal phrases like 'Nation in a Mustard Ball,' portrays the philosopher as capricious and his beliefs as whimsical, undermining the seriousness of the philosophical inquiry presented by Fontenelle.

Fontenelle's general examples of microscopic life and spontaneous generation are replaced with specific, vivid, and localized references like 'our Virtuoso's,' 'Pepper Worms,' 'Dolphins, sporting in the Ocean,' and 'sharpness of Vinegar.' This anglicizes the scientific context, potentially to flatter English scientific achievements (e.g., of the Royal Society 'Virtuosos'), and sensationalizes the discoveries, shifting the tone from Fontenelle's more sober popular science to something more overtly spectacular. The concluding general statement about new species appearing is replaced by a vague list of English-centric examples.

chunks.source_manual: <P050>Beaucoup de Corps qui paroissent solides <UP></UP>, ne sont que des amas de ces Animaux imperceptibles, qui y trouvent pour leurs mouvemens autant de liberté qu'il leur en faut. Une feüille d'Arbre est un petit Monde habité par des Vermisseaux invisibles, à qui elle paroist d'une étenduë immense, qui y connoissent des Montagnes & des Abismes, & qui d'un costé de la feüille à l'autre n'ont pas plus de communication avec les autres Vermisseaux qui y vivent, que nous avec nos Antipodes. A plus forte raison, ce me semble, une <RW>grosse</RW> Planete sera-t-elle un Monde habité. On a trouvé jusque dans des especes de pierres tres-dures de petits Vers sans nombre, qui y étoient logez de toutes parts dans des vuides insensibles, & qui ne se nourrissoient que de la substance de ces pierres qu'ils rongeoient. Figurez-vous combien il y avoit de ces petits Vers, & pendant combien d'années ils subsistoient de la grosseur d'un grain de sable; & sur cet exemple, quand la Lune ne seroit qu'un amas de rochers, je la ferois plûtost ronger par ses Habitans que de n'y en pas mettre. Enfin tout est vivant, tout est animé <UP></UP>: mettez toutes ces especes d'Animaux nouvellement découvertes, & mesme toutes celles que l'on conçoit aisément qui sont encore à découvrir, avec celles que l'on a toûjours veuës, vous trouverez assurément que la Terre est bien peuplée, & que la Nature y a si liberalement répandu les Animaux, qu'elle ne s'est pas mise en peine que l'on en vist seulement la moitié. Croirez-vous qu'aprés qu'elle a poussé icy sa fecondité jusqu'à l'excés, elle a esté pour toutes les autres Planetes d'une sterilité à n'y rien produire de vivant?</P050> <P051>Ma raison est assez bien convaincuë, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, mais mon imagination est accablée de la multitude infinie des Habitans de toutes ces Planetes, & embarrassée de la diversité qu'il faut établir entre eux; car je voy bien que la Nature, selon qu'elle est ennemie des repetitions, les aura tous faits différens, mais comment se representer cela? Ce n'est pas à l'imagination à prétendre le représenter, répondis-je, elle n'est pas propre à aller plus loin que les yeux. On peut seulement apercevoir d'une certaine veuë universelle, la diversité que la Nature doit avoir mise entre tous ces Mondes. Tous les visages sont en general sur un mesme modele; mais ceux de deux grandes Nations, comme des Européens, si vous voulez, & des Africains, paroissent estre faits sur deux modeles particuliers, & il faudroit encore trouver le modele des visages de chaque Famille. Quel secret doit avoir eu la Nature pour varier en tant de manieres une chose aussi simple qu'un visage? Nous ne sommes dans l'Univers que comme une petite Famille, dont tous les visages se ressemblent; dans une autre Planete, c'est une autre Famille dont les visages ont un autre air. <UP></UP>.</P051> <P052>Apparemment les differences augmentent à mesure que l'on s'éloigne, & qui verroit un Habitant de la Lune, & un Habitant de la Terre, remarqueroit bien qu'ils seroient de deux Mondes plus voisions qu'un Habitant de la Terre & un Habitant de Saturne. Icy, <NCP>par exemple</NCP>, on a l'usage de la voix, ailleurs on ne parle que par signes, plus loin on ne parle point du tout. Icy le raisonnemét se forme entierement par l'experience; ailleurs l'experience y ajoûte fort peu de chose, plus loin les Vieillards n'en sçavent pas plus que les Enfants. Icy on se tourmente de l'avenir plus que du passé; plus loin on ne se tourmente ny de l'un ny de l'autre, & ceux-là ne sont peut-estre pas les plus malheureux. On dit qu'il pourroit bien nous manquer un sixiéme Sens naturel, qui nous aprendroit beaucoup de choses que nous ignorons. Ce sixiéme Sens est apparemment dans quelque autre Monde, où il manque quelqu'un des cinq que nous possedons. Peut-estre mesme y a-t-il effectivement un grand nombre de Sens naturels; mais dans le partage que nous avons fait avec les Habitans des autres Planetes, il ne nous en est écheu que cinq, dont nous nous contentons faute d'en connoistre d'autres. Nos Sciences ont de certaines bornes que l'Esprit humain n'a jamais pû passer; il y a un point où elles nous manquent tout à coup, le reste est pour d'autres Mondes, où quelque chose de ce que nous sçavons est inconnu. <RW>Cette Planete-cy</RW> joüit des douceurs de l'Amour, mais elle est toûjours desolée en plusieurs de ses parties par les fureurs de la Guerre. Dans une autre Planete on joüit d'une Paix éternelle, mais au milieu de cette Paix on ne connoist point l'Amour, & on s'ennuye. Enfin ce que la Nature pratique en petit entre les hommes pour la distribution du bonheur où des talens, elle l'aura sans doute pratiqué en grand entre les Mondes, & elle se sera bien souvenuë de mettre en usage ce secret merveilleux qu'elle a de diversifier toutes choses, & de les égaler en mesme temps que les compensations.</P052>
chunks.target_manual: <P040>Nay, to shew you that they can see <UP>as far into a Milstone as Descartes himself</UP>, they have discover'd that several, even of the most solid Bodies, are nothing but an immense swarm of imperceptible Animals: Do but consider this little Leaf; why it is a great World, of a vast extent, what Mountains, what Abysses are there in it? the Insects of one side, know no more of their fellow Creatures on t' other side, then you and I can tell what they are now doing at the Antipodes; is it not reason then that a great Planet should be inhabited? In the hardest Stones, for Example, in Marble, there are an infinity of Worms, which fill up the vacuums, and feed upon the substance of the Stone; fancy then millions of living Creatures to subsist; many years on a grain of Sand; so that were the Moon but one continued Rock, she should be gnaw'd by these invisible Mites, (as <UP>if she were a green Cheese) rather than not be inhabited: In short, every thing is animated, and the Stones upon Salisbury Plain are as much alive, as a Hive of Bees</UP>; imagine then those Animals which are yet undiscovered, and add them and those which are but lately discover'd, to those we have always seen, you will find the Earth swarms with Inhabitants. Why then should Nature, which is fruitful to an excess here, be so very barren in the rest of the Planets? I must own, said the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, you have convinc'd my Reason, but you have confounded my Fancy, with such variety, that I cannot imagine how Nature, which hates Repetitions, should produce so many different kinds. There is no need of Fancy, I reply'd, do but trust your Eyes, and you will easily perceive how Nature diversifies in these several Worlds.</P040> <P041>All humane Faces, in general, are of the same Model, and yet the Europeans and the Africans have two particular Moulds; nay, commonly every Family have a different Form; what secret then has Nature to shew so much variety in the single Face? Our World, in respect of the Universe, is but a little Family; all whose Faces have some resemblance; in another Place, there is another Family, whose Faces have a different Air and Fashion; <UP>the difference too increaseth with the distance, for whosoever should see an Inhabitant of the Moon, and an Inhabitant of the Earth, would soon perceive they were nearer Neighbours than one of the Earth, and one of Saturn; here, for Example, we have the use of Voice, in another World, they speak by Signs, and at a greater distance they do not speak at all; here our Reason is form'd by Experience, in the next World, Experience contributes little towards it; and in the next to that, old Men know no more than Children; here we are troubled more with what is to come, than with what is past; further off, they are not concern'd with either, which by the way, I think, is much the better: Here, 'tisthought we want a sixth Sense, which would teach us many things, of which we are now ignorant; this sixth Sense, is apparently in another World, where they want one of the five which we enjoy; nay, perhaps there is a much greater number of Senses, but in the Partition we have made of 'em with the Inhabitants of the other Planets, there are but five fall'n to our share, with which we are well contented, for want of being acquainted with the rest: Our Sciences have bounds, which the wit of Man could never pass; there is a point where they fail us on a sudden, the rest is reserv'd for other Worlds, where somewhat which we know, is unknown to them. This Planet enjoys the pleasures of Love, but lies desolate in several places by the fury of War; in another Planet, they enjoy a perpetual Peace, yet in the midst of that Peace, know nothing of Love, and time lies on their hands; in a word, that which Nature practises here in little, in distributing her Gifts among Mankind; she does at large in other Worlds, where she makes use of that admirable secret she hath to diversifie all things, and at the same time makes 'em equal, by compensating for the inequality; this I confess is on the Borders of Nonsense, but a Man is ne'er the less a Philosopher for being a little obscure, if not unintelligible.</UP></P041>

explanations: The English translation prefaces Fontenelle's scientific observation with 'Nay, to shew you that they can see as far into a Milstone as Descartes himself,'. This leading phrase, entirely absent in the French original, introduces a specific reference to Descartes and a colloquial English idiom. This addition alters the original's straightforward scientific tone by framing the subsequent claim through a Cartesian lens and an English cultural expression, manipulating the reader's perception by adding an unoriginal layer of authority or cultural familiarity.

The English translation inserts the parenthetical simile '(as if she were a green Cheese)' into the discussion about the Moon's inhabitants. This culturally specific English folk reference for the Moon is absent in Fontenelle's original. Its inclusion domesticates the text for an English audience and adds a layer of whimsy not intended by Fontenelle, thus manipulating the tone and cultural framing of the original passage.

The translation inserts the clause 'and the Stones upon Salisbury Plain are as much alive, as a Hive of Bees;' immediately after Fontenelle's general philosophical statement 'Enfin tout est vivant, tout est animé' (In short, everything is living, everything is animated). This addition localizes a universal philosophical idea to a specific English context (Salisbury Plain, site of Stonehenge) and introduces a vivid but entirely new simile. This alters the universality of Fontenelle's statement and manipulates the reader by grounding it in a culturally specific image not present in the original.

The original French text refers to the female interlocutor as 'la Marquise.' The English translation changes this title to 'the Countess.' This substitution alters a specific detail of the character and the French setting. It anglicizes the character and potentially makes the title more familiar to an English readership, subtly shifting the cultural specificity of the original and thus manipulating the reader's perception of the character's identity within the dialogue's frame.

The French text states that imagination ('Fancy' in English context) is not suited to go 'plus loin que les yeux' (further than the eyes) and that one can only perceive nature's diversity through 'une certaine veuë universelle' (a certain universal view/perspective), implying a conceptual understanding beyond direct sight. The English translation alters this to an imperative 'do but trust your Eyes, and you will easily perceive...', which simplifies the original's philosophical point about the limits of imagination and the distinct mode of perception required. This manipulates the reader by misrepresenting the nature of understanding Fontenelle describes.

Fontenelle's narrator speculates mildly, '& ceux-là ne sont peut-estre pas les plus malheureux' (and those are perhaps not the most unhappy). The English translation changes this into a more direct, colloquial, and personal opinion interjected by the narrator/translator: 'which by the way, I think, is much the better:'. This insertion alters the original's detached, speculative tone to a more asserted personal judgment, manipulating the character of the narrative voice.

The English translation appends a substantial concluding remark: 'this I confess is on the Borders of Nonsense, but a Man is ne'er the less a Philosopher for being a little obscure, if not unintelligible.' This commentary is entirely absent from Fontenelle's original French text, which ends on a serious philosophical note about nature's grand design. The addition drastically alters the tone of the passage, introducing a layer of self-deprecation, skepticism, or flippancy towards the preceding philosophical speculation. This manipulates the reader's understanding of the original's intellectual seriousness and intent, possibly as a strategy to temper its reception for an English audience potentially wary of radical French ideas during this period.

chunks.source_manual: <P053>Etes-vous contente, Madame, ajoûtay-je en quittant le ton serieux? Vous ay-je dubité assez de chimeres? Vrayment, répondit-elle, il me semble que j'ay presentement moins de peine à attraper les differences de tous ces Mondes. Mon imagination travaille sur le plan que vous m'avez donné. Je me represente comme je puis des Caracteres & des Coûtumes extraordinaire pour les Habitans des Planetes, & je leur compose mesme des figures tout-à-fait bizarres. Je ne vous les pourrois pas décrire, mais je voy pourtant quelque chose. Pour ces figures-là, repliquay-je, je vous conseille d'en laisser le soin aux Songes que vous aurez cette nuit. Nous verrons demain s'ils vous auront bien servie, & s'ils vous auront appris comment sont faits les Habitants de quelque Planete.</P053>
chunks.target_manual: <P042>But is it not time, Madam, to be serious, how will you dispose of all these Notions? Trouble not your self, says she, Fancy is a great Traveller; I already comprehend these several Worlds, and represent to my self their different Characters and Customs; some of 'em, I assure you, are very extraordinary; I see at this moment, a thousand different Figures, tho' I cannot well describe 'em. Oh leave 'em, I reply'd, to your Dreams, they will represent 'em very faithfully.</P042>

Vrayment, répondit-elle, il me semble que j'ay presentement moins de peine à attraper les differences de tous ces Mondes. Mon imagination travaille sur le plan que vous m'avez donné.
Je me represente comme je puis des Caracteres & des Coûtumes extraordinaire pour les Habitans des Planetes, & je leur compose mesme des figures tout-à-fait bizarres.
Pour ces figures-là, repliquay-je, je vous conseille d'en laisser le soin aux Songes que vous aurez cette nuit.
Nous verrons demain s'ils vous auront bien servie, & s'ils vous auront appris comment sont faits les Habitants de quelque Planete.
target_segments: But is it not time, Madam, to be serious, how will you dispose of all these Notions?
Trouble not your self, says she, Fancy is a great Traveller; I already comprehend these several Worlds, and represent to my self their different Characters and Customs;
some of 'em, I assure you, are very extraordinary; I see at this moment, a thousand different Figures, tho' I cannot well describe 'em.
Oh leave 'em, I reply'd, to your Dreams, they will represent 'em very faithfully.
explanations: The translation inverts the philosopher's stance. In the original, he asks if the Marquise is content with the "chimeres" (fantasies) offered *after leaving* a serious tone. The translation has him asking if it's time *to become* serious and how she will "dispose of" "Notions." This alters his playful tone and role, making him seem concerned with seriousness and practicality, rather than guiding imaginative exploration. "Chimeres" is also softened to "Notions," losing the original's acknowledgment of the discussion's speculative nature.

The translation adds "Trouble not your self" and "Fancy is a great Traveller," altering the Marquise's tone to be more independently assertive. Her "il me semble que j'ay presentement moins de peine à attraper les differences" (I now have less difficulty grasping) is changed to the more definitive "I already comprehend," removing the nuance of her learning process. The omission of "Mon imagination travaille sur le plan que vous m'avez donné" (My imagination works on the plan you have given me) erases her acknowledgment of the philosopher's guidance, making her imaginative process seem less structured by his "plan."

The original "Je me represente comme je puis" (I represent to myself as best I can) highlights the Marquise's effort. The translation shifts this to "some of 'em, I assure you, are very extraordinary," focusing on assertion rather than process. The active "je leur compose mesme des figures" (I even compose figures for them) becomes the more passive "I see... a thousand different Figures," with "a thousand" being an unoriginal exaggeration. This downplays her active imaginative construction and introduces hyperbole.

The translation adds "Oh," making the philosopher's reply more casual. More importantly, it adds "they will represent 'em very faithfully." The original philosopher only advises leaving the figures to dreams, without promising faithful representation. This addition ascribes an unwarranted accuracy to dreams, potentially misaligning with Fontenelle's Enlightenment emphasis on reasoned, albeit imaginative, scientific popularization.

The philosopher's final sentence from the source text, "Nous verrons demain s'ils vous auront bien servie, & s'ils vous auront appris comment sont faits les Habitants de quelque Planete." (We will see tomorrow if they [dreams] will have served you well, & if they will have taught you how the Inhabitants of some Planet are made.), is entirely omitted in the translation (indicated by an empty target segment as the provided English paragraph ends before this sentence). This omission is significant as the sentence sets up an expectation for continued discussion and reflection, reinforcing the pedagogical nature of their conversations and the ongoing learning process. Its absence curtails the dialogue prematurely, removes this forward-looking, reflective element, and diminishes the emphasis on evaluating the insights gained from imaginative exercises, thereby altering the perceived intent and completeness of the interaction.

chunks.source_manual: <P055><SC>Les songes ne furent point heureux: ils representerent toûjours quelque chose qui ressembloit à ce que l'on voit icy. J'eus lieu de reprocher à la <IIM>Marquise</IIM> ce que nous reprochent à la veüe de nos Tableaux, de certains Peuples qui ne font jamaïs que des peintures bizarres & grotesques. Bon, nous disent-ils, cela est tout fait comme des hommes, il n'y a pas là d'imagination. Il falut donc se resoudre à ignorer les figures des Habitans de toutes ces Planetes, & se contenter d'en deviner ce que nous pourrions, en continuant le Voyage des Mondes que nous avions commencé.</SC> Nous en estions à Venus. On est bien seur, dis-je à la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, que Venus tourne sur elle-mesme, <SC>mais on ne sçait pas bien en quel temps</SC>, ny par consequent combien ses jours durent. Pour ses années, elles ne sont que de huit mois, puis qu'elle tourne en ce temps-là autour du Soleil. Come elle est quarante fois plus petite que la Terre, la Terre de dedans Venus paroist une Planete quarante fois plus grande, que Venus ne nous paroist d'icy; & comme la Lune est aussi quarante fois plus petite que la Terre, elle paroist dedans Venus à peu prés de la mesme grandeur dont Venus nous paroist d'icy.</P055>
chunks.target_manual: <P045><UP>I Have been told of a Physician that makes his Patients dream as he pleases, by prescribing such a Specifick for their Supper, as works those impressions he would have on the Fancy; of what use he may be to the modern Poets, I leave to the curious; and return to the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, who either did not dream at all, or nothing to the purpose</UP>; so that continuing our Voyage to the other Worlds, we could only guess at their Inhabitants. We were come to Venus, and I told her, that Venus certainly turn'd on it self, tho' no body could tell in what time, and consequently were ignorant how long her Day lasted; but her Year was compos'd of eight Months, because 'tis in that time she turns round the Sun: And seeing Venus is forty times less than the Earth, the Earth appears (to them in Venus) to be a Planet, forty times bigger than Venus appears to us on the Earth; and as the Moon is forty times lesser than the Earth, so she seems to be just of the same magnitude, to the Inhabitants of Venus, as here Venus seems to us.</P045>

explanations: The original French text opens the paragraph with a philosophical reflection by the narrator on the limitations of human imagination in envisioning alien life, drawing an analogy to artistic representation and the difficulty of creating something truly novel. This entire section, crucial for its commentary on human perception and creativity, is omitted in the English translation. It is replaced with an unrelated anecdote about a physician who can induce specific dreams in patients and a brief, dismissive comment about poets. This substitution constitutes a significant addition of entirely new material and a complete omission of Fontenelle's original thought. This manipulation fundamentally alters the intellectual content and tone of the passage, removing a nuanced discussion and replacing it with a trivial story, thereby changing the reader's perception of the narrator's concerns and the depth of the dialogue.

The French phrase "à peu prés de la mesme grandeur" (approximately of the same magnitude/size), used to describe the apparent size of the Moon as seen from Venus, indicates an estimation or approximation. The English translation renders this as "just of the same magnitude," implying exactness. This alteration subtly changes the scientific precision of Fontenelle's statement, presenting the comparison as more definitive and mathematically precise than the more cautious and scientifically modest phrasing in the original text.

The French phrase "de dedans Venus" (literally "from inside Venus," meaning "as seen from Venus"), which establishes the vantage point for observing Earth, is translated and expanded to "(to them in Venus)". This addition explicitly introduces observers ("them") into the astronomical description. While Fontenelle's work speculates on inhabitants, the original phrasing here is more general, referring to a location. The explicit addition of "them" subtly manipulates the reader's perception by making the presence of sentient observers more concrete and immediate in this specific clause than the original text strictly implies, thereby reinforcing the theme of inhabited worlds more directly.

Similar to the previous instance, the French term "dedans Venus" (from within Venus), indicating the viewpoint for observing the Moon, is translated and specified as "to the Inhabitants of Venus". The original text's "dedans Venus" simply indicates a location or perspective. The translation's choice to explicitly name "the Inhabitants of Venus" as the observers is an addition. This manipulates the reader's understanding by making the presence of these inhabitants an explicit part of the astronomical observation, rather than a general perspective from the planet Venus, thus constantly foregrounding the notion of populated worlds.

chunks.source_manual: <P056>Vous m'affligez, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>. Je voy bien que la Terre n'est pas pour Vénus l'Etoile du Berger, & la Mere des Amours, comme Vénus l'est pour la Terre; car la Terre de dedans Vénus paroist trop grande, mais la Lune qui y paroist de la mesme grandeur dont Vénus nous paroist d'icy, est justement taillée comme il faut pour y estre Mere des Amours, & Etoile du Berger <NCE></NCE>. Ces noms ne peuvent convenir qu'à une petite Planete qui soit jolie, claire, brillante, & qui ait un air galant. <UP></UP> C'est asseurément une destinée agréable pour nostre Lune que de presider aux Amours des Habitans de Venus; ces Gens là doivent bien entendre la galanterie. Oh! sans doute, répondis-je, le menu Peuple de Venus n'est composé que de Celadons & de Silvandres, & leurs Conversations le plus communes valent les plus belles de Clesie. <UP></UP> Le climat est tres-favorable aux Amours. Venus est plus proche que nous du Soleil, & elle en reçoit une lumiere plus vive & plus de chaleur.</P056>
chunks.target_manual: <P046>I see then, says the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, that the Earth is not to Venus, what Venus is to the Earth; I mean, that the Earth is too bigg to be the Mother of Love, or the Shepherd's Star to Venus; but the Moon, which appears to Venus, of the same bigness that Venus appears to us, is assign'd to be the Mother of Love, and <NCE>Shepherds Star to Venus</NCE>; for such names are only proper for a little brisk airy Planet, bright, and shining as the Goddess her self. Oh, blessed Moon, how happy art thou, to preside over the Amours of those gallant People, where all they say, is soft and moving, <UP>and perfectly refin'd from the dross of our Wits, who are fitter for a Bear-Garden than a Circle? How gross is their Courtship? how mean their Raillery? without any distinction of time, place, or person; they make Love, (as they call it) but one way, and the form is the same, at a Farce, or Funeral. Be not so very severe, I reply'd, if some of our Beaux speak plain English, some of your Belles, like 'em ne're the worse for't: The art of Love is as much improv'd as the art of War, the Generals of this Age take a Town in two days, which in the last, held out as many years; and the Roses, Lillies, Pearls, and Rubies, (a whining Lovers train of Artillery)</UP> are grown as useless as Bows and Arrows: tho' after all, I must own they have another Standard in the Planet Venus; there <UP>Clelia</UP> and Parthenissa, is below the language of Grooms and Chamber Maids; and every Porter and Car-Man a perfect Sir Courtly; but then consider the difference of Climats; Venus is much nearer than the Earth is to the Sun, from whence she receives a more vigorous and active influence.</P046>

How gross is their Courtship? how mean their Raillery? without any distinction of time, place, or person; they make Love, (as they call it) but one way, and the form is the same, at a Farce, or Funeral.

Be not so very severe, I reply'd, if some of our Beaux speak plain English, some of your Belles, like 'em ne're the worse for't: The art of Love is as much improv'd as the art of War, the Generals of this Age take a Town in two days, which in the last, held out as many years; and the Roses, Lillies, Pearls, and Rubies, (a whining Lovers train of Artillery) are grown as useless as Bows and Arrows: tho' after all, I must own they have another Standard in the Planet Venus; there Clelia and Parthenissa, is below the language of Grooms and Chamber Maids; and every Porter and Car-Man a perfect Sir Courtly;
but then consider the difference of Climats; Venus is much nearer than the Earth is to the Sun, from whence she receives a more vigorous and active influence.
explanations: The original French 'Vous m'affligez' (You afflict me/distress me) indicating the Marquise's emotional reaction, is translated as 'I see then,' which removes the expressed emotion and changes her response to a purely cognitive one. This alters the character's immediate sentiment and the tone of the exchange. The change of 'Marquise' to 'Countess' is also an alteration, though the primary manipulation here is the shift in expressed feeling.

The original description of the planet 'qui ait un air galant' (that has a gallant air) is replaced with 'as the Goddess her self.' This substitution shifts the quality of 'gallantry' from an intrinsic characteristic of the planet to a comparison with a mythological deity (Venus), introducing a divine personification not present in Fontenelle's phrasing. Additionally, 'jolie' (pretty) becomes 'brisk airy,' changing the specific aesthetic quality attributed to the planet.

The Marquise's concise observation about the Moon's destiny and the Venusians' skill in gallantry is massively expanded into a direct address ('Oh, blessed Moon') and a lengthy, biting satire on contemporary English social customs, particularly regarding courtship and wit ('our Wits,' 'Bear-Garden,' 'Farce, or Funeral'). This extensive addition is entirely absent in the source text, profoundly altering the Marquise's (Countess's) speech, character, and the focus of the dialogue by inserting social commentary specific to late 17th-century England.

The philosopher's affirmative reply, which uses pastoral romance characters (Celadons, Silvandres) and 'Clélie' to illustrate the refinement of Venusians, is completely replaced. The translation substitutes a defensive commentary on English courtship ('our Beaux'), a modern military metaphor for love, and a dismissal of traditional love poetry. Furthermore, the reference to 'Clélie' is inverted: instead of Venusians speaking with its refinement, the sophisticated language of 'Clelia and Parthenissa' is deemed inferior to common speech on Venus, where even porters are 'a perfect Sir Courtly' (a character from English Restoration comedy, Sir Courtly Nice, 1685). This drastically changes the philosopher's argument, tone, and cultural frame of reference, injecting contemporary English social and literary debates.

The original text states, 'Le climat est tres-favorable aux Amours' (The climate is very favorable to Loves), which is omitted directly in the translation, removing a clear link between climate and disposition. More significantly, the concrete physical description of Venus receiving 'une lumiere plus vive & plus de chaleur' (a more vivid light and more heat) from the sun is transformed into the more abstract 'a more vigorous and active influence.' This shifts the explanation from a direct, scientifically-phrased observation about light and heat to a vaguer, more generalized 'influence,' potentially imbuing it with less precise, almost astrological or temperamental connotations, thereby subtly altering the scientific popularization tone of Fontenelle's work.

chunks.source_manual: <P057>Je vois presentement, interrompit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, comment sont faits les Habitans de Venus. Ils ressemblent aux Mores Grenadins; un petit Peuple noir, brûlé du Soleil, plein d'esprit & de feu, toûjours amoureux, faisant des Vers, aimant la Musique, inventant tous les jours des Festes, des Danses, & des Tournois. Permettez-moy de vous dire, Madame, repliquay-je, que vous ne connoissez guere bien les Habitans de Venus. Nos Mores Grenadins n'auroient esté auprés d'eux que des Lappons & des Groënlandois pour la froideur & pour la stupidité.</P057>
chunks.target_manual: <P047>I find, says the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, it is easie enough to guess at the Inhabitants of Venus; they resemble what I have read of the Moors of Granada, who were a little black People, scorch'd with the Sun, witty, full of Fire, very Amorous, much inclin'd to Musick and Poetry, and ever inventing Masques and Turnaments in honour of their Mistresses. Pardon me, Madam, said I, you are little acquainted with the Planet; Granada in all its Glory, was a perfect Greenland to it; and your gallant Moors, in comparison with that People, were as stupid as so many Laplanders.</P047>

explanations: The translation omits 'Festes' (feasts/festivals) and 'Danses' (dances), replacing part of the activities with the more specific 'Masques.' More significantly, it adds the phrase 'in honour of their Mistresses,' a motivation absent in the original. This addition frames Venusian activities primarily through a lens of courtly romance, potentially trivializing their culture or making it conform to specific romantic literary tropes, thereby manipulating the reader's perception of their societal engagements.

The original French uses active participles 'faisant des Vers' (making verses) and 'aimant la Musique' (loving music), depicting direct engagement and strong preference. The translation 'much inclin'd to Musick and Poetry' renders these actions and affections as mere inclinations. This shift from active participation and strong liking to a more passive tendency subtly diminishes the perceived agency and cultural vibrancy of the Venusians, manipulating the reader into viewing them as less actively engaged.

The original 'toûjours amoureux' (always amorous) describes a constant, defining characteristic. The translation 'very Amorous' indicates a high degree of amorousness but does not necessarily convey the same perpetual or inherent nature. This subtle shift can alter the reader's understanding of how fundamental this trait is to the Venusians, potentially making them seem less defined by this constant state and thus more conventional.

The original text focuses on the Marquise's lack of knowledge about the 'Habitans de Venus' (inhabitants of Venus). The translation redirects this to 'the Planet' itself. This shift subtly moves the reader's focus from the speculative and potentially controversial idea of extraterrestrial beings to the safer, astronomical object, thereby manipulating the emphasis of Fontenelle's discussion away from the plurality of (inhabited) worlds.

The original directly likens the 'Mores Grenadins' (Moors of Granada) to 'Lappons & des Groënlandois' (Laplanders and Greenlanders) in both 'froideur & stupidité' (coldness and stupidity) when compared to Venusians. The translation restructures this by first introducing an entirely new comparison: 'Granada in all its Glory, was a perfect Greenland to it' (referring to the planet Venus), changing the subject of comparison from people to a place and adding the embellishment 'in all its Glory.' It also adds 'gallant' to 'Moors' and then presents a simplified comparison regarding only stupidity. This restructuring, with its additions and altered focus, changes the rhetorical impact of the philosopher's refutation by making it more ornate and less direct.

chunks.source_manual: <P058>Mais que sera-ce des Habitants de Mercure? Ils sont encore plus proches du Soleil; il faut qu'ils soient fous à force de vivacité. <UP></UP> Je croy qu'ils n'ont point de memoire, non plus que la plupart des Négres; qu'ils ne font jamais de reflexion sur rien, qu'ils n'agissent qu'à l'aventure, & par des mouvemens subits, & <IIM>qu'enfin c'est dans Mercure que sont les Petites Maisons de l'Univers.</IIM> <NCE></NCE> Ils voyent le Soleil beaucoup plus grand que nous ne le voyons, parce qu'ils en sont beaucoup plus proches. Il leur envoye une lumiere si forte, que s'ils estoient icy, ils ne prendroient nos plus beaux jours que pour de <IIM>tres-foibles</IIM> Crepuscules, & peut-estre n'y pourroient-ils pas distinguer les objets, & la chaleur à laquelle ils sont accoûtumez est si excessive, que celle qu'il fait icy au fond de l'Afrique, suffiroit pour les glacier. Leur année n'est que de trois mois. La durée de leur jour ne nous est point encore connuë, parce que Mercure est si petit & si proche du Soleil, dans les rayons duquel il est presque toûjours perdu, qu'il échappe à toute l'adresse des Astronomes, & qu'on n'a pû encore avoir assez de prise sur luy, pour observer le mouvement qu'il doit avoir sur son centre; mais sa petitesse fait croire qu'il acheve ce tour en peu de temps; que par consequent le jour de Mercure est fort court, & que les Habitans voyent le Soleil comme un <RW>grand poêle ardent</RW>, peu éloigné de leurs testes, & qui va d'une rapidité prodigieuse. Cela en est mieux pour eux, car apparemment ils soûpirent aprés la nuit. Ils sont éclairez pendant ce temps-là de Venus,& de la Terre, qui leur doivent paroistre assez grandes. Pour les autres Planetes, comme elles sont au-delà de la <IIM>Terre vers le Firmament</IIM>, ils les voyent plus petites que nous ne les voyons, & n'en reçoivent que bien peu de lumiere, peut-estre n'en reçoivent-ils point du tout. Les Etoles Fixes sont aussi plus petites pour eux, & même il doit y en avoir beaucoup qui disparoissent entierement; c'est, selon moy, une perte. Je suis bien fàché de voir cette <RW>grande voûte ornée de mois d'Etoiles, & de ne voir celles qui me resteroient</RW>, que plus petites, & d'une couleur plus effacée. <SC></SC>.</P058>
chunks.target_manual: <P048>But what do you think then of the Inhabitants of Mercury? They are yet nearer to the Sun, and are so full of Fire, <UP>that they are absolutely mad; I fancy, they have no memory at all, like most of the Negroes, that they make no reflections, and what they do is by sudden starts, and perfect hap-hazard; <NCE>in short, Mercury is the Bedlam of the Universe</NCE>; the Sun appears to them much greater than it does to us, because they are much nearer to it than we; it sends them so vast and strong a light, that the most glorious day here, would be no more with them than a declining Page 97 twilight: I know not if they can distinguish Objects, but the heat to which they are accustom'd, is so excessive, that they would be starved with cold in the Torrid Zone; their year is but three Months, but we know not the exact length of their Day, because Mercury is so little, and so near the Sun; it is, (as it were) lost in his Rays, and is very hardly discover'd by the Astronomers; so that they cannot observe how it moves on its Centre, but because it is so little, fancy it compleats its motion in a little time; so that by consequence, the day there is very short, and the Sun appears to them like <RW>a vast fiery Furnace at a little distance</RW>, whose motion is prodigiously swift and rapid; and during their Night, Venus and the Earth (which must appear considerably big) give light to them; as for the other Planets which are beyond the Earth, <RW>towards the Firmament</RW>, they appear less to them in Mercury, than they do to us here, and they receive but little light from them, perhaps none at all; the fix'd Stars likewise seem less to them, and some of 'em totally disappear, which were I there, I should esteem a very great</UP> loss. <SC></SC></P048>
