explanations: The original "il faut qu'ils soient fous à force de vivacité" (they must be mad from an excess of vivacity/liveliness) is translated with a shift in cause and an intensification. "Vivacité" (liveliness, quickness of mind) is replaced by "so full of Fire," a more elemental and potentially less nuanced concept. Furthermore, "il faut qu'ils soient fous" (they must be mad, or it is necessary that they are mad), which carries a sense of logical deduction, is rendered as "they are absolutely mad," which is a more direct, emphatic, and definitive assertion, removing some of the speculative tone.

The French "Petites Maisons" (literally 'small houses'), a euphemism for insane asylums, is translated as "Bedlam," referring to a specific and notorious London asylum. This cultural substitution localizes the reference for an English audience but replaces the euphemistic and general French term with a concrete, culturally charged English one, altering the tone and specificity.

The French "de tres-foibles Crepuscules" (very weak twilights) describes the low intensity of light. The English "a declining twilight" (ignoring the "Page 97" artifact, which is likely a scanning error in the provided target text) shifts the meaning to emphasize the process of twilight fading or diminishing, rather than its static state of weakness. This subtly alters the imagery from a state of dimness to an ongoing action of fading.

The original "peut-estre n'y pourroient-ils pas distinguer les objets" (perhaps they could not distinguish objects there) expresses a possibility about the Mercurians' perception. The translation "I know not if they can distinguish Objects" shifts the uncertainty to the speaker's state of knowledge ("I know not") rather than an objective possibility about the Mercurians. This subtly alters the nature of the speculation from a characteristic of the Mercurians' potential experience to a limitation of the narrator's understanding.

The translation replaces the more evocative and geographically specific "au fond de l'Afrique" (deep in Africa) with the more formal, scientific term "in the Torrid Zone." This changes the imagery and register, making it less picturesque and more abstractly geographical. Additionally, "suffiroit pour les glacier" (would be enough to freeze them) is rendered as "they would be starved with cold," which is a more dramatic and idiomatic expression, potentially intensifying the original meaning more than a direct translation of "freeze."

The original "fait croire" (makes one believe/leads to the belief) suggests a logical inference drawn from the planet's smallness. The translation "fancy it compleats" (using "fancy" as a verb implying supposition or imagination) attributes this belief more to whim or less grounded speculation, rather than an impersonal conclusion suggested by the evidence. This changes the perceived basis of the scientific reasoning from observation-based deduction to a more subjective fancy.

The first sentence of the source segment, "Cela en est mieux pour eux, car apparemment ils soûpirent aprés la nuit." (That is better for them, because apparently they sigh after/long for the night.), is entirely omitted in the translation. The target text directly translates the second sentence ("Ils sont éclairez..."). This omission removes the philosopher's speculation about the Mercurians' relief at nightfall due to the harsh conditions of their day, thereby losing a piece of characterization of the inhabitants and their adaptation to their environment, subtly altering the reader's perception of life on Mercury.

The translation alters the philosopher's statement: 'c'est, selon moy, une perte' (it is, in my opinion, a loss) becomes the more conditional, personalized, and intensified 'which were I there, I should esteem a very great loss.' Furthermore, the entire subsequent sentence in the source, "Je suis bien fàché de voir cette grande voûte ornée de mois d'Etoiles, & de ne voir celles qui me resteroient, que plus petites, & d'une couleur plus effacée.." (I am very sorry/upset to see this great vault adorned with fewer Stars [assuming "mois" is a typo for "moins"], and to see those that would remain to me, only smaller, and of a more faded color..), is omitted as the English paragraph ends. This combination of alteration and omission significantly changes the tone from a direct statement of opinion and sorrow to a more hypothetical and truncated reflection.

chunks.source_manual: <P059>Je ne suis pas si touchée, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, de cette perte-là que sont les <IIM>Habitans de Mercure</IIM>, que de l'incommodité qu'ils reçoivent de l'excés de la chaleur. Je voudrois bien que nous les soulageassions un peu. Donnons à Mercure de longues & d'abondantes pluyes qui le rafraischissent, comme on dit qu'il en tombe icy dans les Pays chauds pendant des quatre mois entiers, justement dans les saisons les plus chaudes.</P059> <P060>Cela se peut, repris-je, & mesme nous pouvons rafraîchir encore Mercure d'une autre façon. Il y a des Pays dans la Chine qui doivent estre tres-chauds par leur situation, & où il fait pourtant de grands froids pendant les mois de Juillet & d'Aoust, jusque-là que les Rivieres se gelent. C'est que ces contrées là ont beaucoup de Salpêtre; les exhalaisons en sont fort froides, & la force de la chaleur les fait sortir de la Terre en grande abondance. Mercure sera, si vous voulez, une petite Planete toute de <IIM>Salpêtre</IIM>, & le Soleil tirera d'elle-mesme le remede au mal qu'il luy pourroit faire. Ce qu'il y a de seur, c'est que la Nature ne sçauroit faire vivre les Gens qu'où ils peuvent vivre, & que l'habitude jointe à l'ignorance de quelque chose de meilleur, survient, & les y fait vivre agréablement. Ainsi on pourroit même se passer dans Mercure du <IIM>Salpêtre</IIM> & des pluyes.</P060>
chunks.target_manual: <P049>What signifies the loss of a few fix'd Stars, says the <IIM>Countess?</IIM> I pity 'em for the excessive heat <SC>they </SC> endure; let us give 'em some relief, and send Mercury a few of the refreshing Showers they have sometimes four Months together in the hottest Countries during their greatest extremity. Your Fancy is good, Madam, I reply'd, but we will relieve 'em another way; In China there are Countries which are extreamly hot by their Situation: yet in July and August are so cold, that the Rivers are Frozen; the reason is, they are full of Salt-Petre, which being exhal'd in great abundance by the excessive heat of the Sun, makes a perfect Winter at Midsummer. We will fill the little Planet with Salt-petre, and let the Sun shine as hot as he pleases. And yet after all, who knows but the Inhabitants of Mercury may have no occasion either for Rain, or Salt- Petre. If it is a certain truth, that Nature never gives life to any Creature, but where that Creature may live; then thro' Custom, and ignorance of a better Life, those People may live happily.</P049>
source_segments: Je ne suis pas si touchée, dit la Marquise, de cette perte-là que sont les Habitans de Mercure, que de l'incommodité qu'ils reçoivent de l'excés de la chaleur.
Donnons à Mercure de longues & d'abondantes pluyes qui le rafraischissent,
Cela se peut, repris-je, & mesme nous pouvons rafraîchir encore Mercure d'une autre façon.
Mercure sera, si vous voulez, une petite Planete toute de Salpêtre, & le Soleil tirera d'elle-mesme le remede au mal qu'il luy pourroit faire.
C'est que ces contrées là ont beaucoup de Salpêtre; les exhalaisons en sont fort froides, & la force de la chaleur les fait sortir de la Terre en grande abondance.
Ce qu'il y a de seur, c'est que la Nature ne sçauroit faire vivre les Gens qu'où ils peuvent vivre,
target_segments: What signifies the loss of a few fix'd Stars, says the Countess?
send Mercury a few of the refreshing Showers
Your Fancy is good, Madam, I reply'd, but we will relieve 'em another way;
We will fill the little Planet with Salt-petre, and let the Sun shine as hot as he pleases.
the reason is, they are full of Salt-Petre, which being exhal'd in great abundance by the excessive heat of the Sun, makes a perfect Winter at Midsummer.

And yet after all, who knows but the Inhabitants of Mercury may have no occasion either for Rain, or Salt- Petre. If it is a certain truth, that Nature never gives life to any Creature, but where that Creature may live;
explanations: The original French expresses the Marquise's nuanced sentiment, indicating she is less concerned about the loss of stars compared to the inhabitants' discomfort from heat. The translation changes this into a dismissive rhetorical question ('What signifies the loss...?'), making the Countess (Marquise) sound abrupt and as if she completely disregards the loss of stars. This alters her character's tone and the subtlety of her statement, manipulating the reader's perception of her thoughtfulness.

The original French 'longues & d'abondantes pluyes' (long and abundant rains) suggests a significant and plentiful solution proposed by the Marquise. The translation 'a few of the refreshing Showers' drastically reduces the quantity and impact. This change diminishes the scale of her imaginative proposal, subtly altering the perception of her empathy or the generosity of her envisioned aid.

In the original, the philosopher's 'Cela se peut' (That can be/That is possible) affirms the Marquise's preceding idea of rains, and '& mesme' (and even) suggests a collaborative addition of another idea. The translation 'Your Fancy is good, Madam, but...' introduces the term 'Fancy,' which can be subtly patronizing, and the conjunction 'but' reframes the philosopher's response as a polite correction or dismissal of her idea in favor of his own, rather than building upon it. This alters the dynamic of the conversation.

The French 'Mercure sera, si vous voulez... & le Soleil tirera d'elle-mesme le remede...' describes a hypothetical scenario where the Sun itself naturally draws a remedy from Mercury, implying a self-regulating system. The translation 'We will fill... and let the Sun shine as hot as he pleases' replaces this sophisticated scientific popularization of a natural balance with a more assertive human-like intervention ('We will fill') and a colloquial, almost flippant dismissal of the Sun's power, losing the original's scientific nuance.

The target segment adds the phrase 'makes a perfect Winter at Midsummer,' which is not present in the corresponding French explanation of saltpeter's effects. This addition introduces a vivid, somewhat poetic flourish and an interpretive layer that stylizes the scientific explanation. While it adds color, it embellishes Fontenelle's more direct prose, subtly shifting the tone from straightforward popular science to a more dramatized account.

The original French 'Ce qu'il y a de seur, c'est que...' (What is certain is that...) introduces the philosopher's reflection on Nature's adaptability with strong conviction. The English translation significantly weakens this certainty by first introducing a speculative phrase ('And yet after all, who knows but...') and then framing the core idea conditionally ('If it is a certain truth...'). This shift from an assertive, authoritative statement to a more tentative one changes the tone and lessens the perceived certainty of the philosophical and scientific principle being discussed, potentially making the new scientific ideas seem less definitive.

chunks.source_manual: <P061>Aprés Mercure vous sçavez qu'on trouve le Soleil. Il n'y a pas moyen d'y mettre d'Habitans. Le Pourquoy non nous manque-là. Nous jugeons par la Terre qui est habitée, que les autres Corps de la mesme espece qu'elle, doivent l'estre aussi; mais le Soleil n'est point un Corps de la mesme espece que la Terre, ny que les autres Planetes. Il est la source de toute cette lumiere que les Planetes ne font que se renvoyer les unes aux autres, aprés l'avoir reçeüe de luy. Elles ne peuvent faire, pour ainsi dire, des échanges entre elles, mais elles ne la peuvent produire. Luy seul tire de soy-mesme cette pretieuse substance; il la pousse avec force de tous costez; de là elle revient à la rencontre de tout ce qui est solide, & d'une Planete à l'autre il s'épand de longues & vastes traisnées de lumieres qui se croisent & se traversent, & s'entrelassent en mille façons diferentes, & forment d'admirables tissus de la plus riche matiere qui soit au monde. Aussi le Soleil est-il placé dans le centre, qui est le lieu le plus commode d'où il la puisse distribuer également, & animer tout par sa chaleur <NCP></NCP>. Le Soleil est donc un Corps <UP>particulier</UP>, mais quelle sorte de Corps? On est bien embarrassé à le dire. On avoit toûjours crû que c'estoit un feu tres-pur, mais on s'en desabusa au commencement de ce <IIM>Siecle</IIM>, qu'on apperceut des taches sur sa surface. Comme on avoit découvert peu de temps auparavant de nouvelles Planetes dont je vous parleray; que tout le <IIM>Monde Philosophe</IIM> n'avoit l'esprit remply d'autre chose, & qu'enfin les nouvelles Planetes s'estoient mises à la mode, on jugea aussi-tost que ces taches en estoient; <UP>qu'elles avoyent un mouvement autour du Soleil</UP>, & qu'elles nous en cachoient necessairement quelque partie, en tournant leur moitié obscure vers nous. Déja les Sçavans faisoient leur Cour de ces pretendües Planetes à tous les Princes de l'Europe. Les uns leur donnoient le nom d'un Prince, les autres d'un autre, & peut-estre il y auroit eu querelle entre-eux à qui seroit demeuré le maistre des taches pour les nommer comme il eust voulu...</P061>
chunks.target_manual: <P050>After Mercury comes the Sun, but there is no possibility of peopling it, nor no room left for a wherefore. By the Earth which is inhabited, we judge that other Bodies of the same Nature may be likewise inhabited; but the Sun is a Body not like the Earth or any of the Planets, the Sun is the source or Fountain of Light, which tho' it is sent from one Planet to another, and receives several alterations by the way, yet all originally proceeds from the Sun, he draws from himself that precious substance which he emits from all sides, and which reflects when it meets with a solid Body, and spreads from one Planet to another those long and vast trains of Light which cross, strike thro', and intermingle in a thousand different fashions, and make <NCP>(if I may so say,)</NCP> the Richest Tissu's in the World. The Sun likewise is placed in the Centre, from whence with most convenience, he may equally distribute and animate by his heat; it is then a particular Body, <UP>but what sort of Body has often puzled better heads than mine</UP>. It was thought formerly a Body of pure Fire, and that Opinion passed currant till the beginning of this Age; when they perceived several spots on its surface. A little after they had discover'd new Planets, (of which, hereafter) which some said were those Spots; for those Planets moving round the Sun, when they turned their dark half to us, must necessarily hide part of it; and had not the Learned with these pretended Planets made their Court before to most of the Princes in Europe, giving the name of this Prince to one, and of that Prince to another Planet; I believe they would have quarrel'd who should be Master of these spots, that they might have nam'd them as they pleas'd.</P050>

Déja les Sçavans faisoient leur Cour de ces pretendües Planetes à tous les Princes de l'Europe. Les uns leur donnoient le nom d'un Prince, les autres d'un autre, & peut-estre il y auroit eu querelle entre-eux à qui seroit demeuré le maistre des taches pour les nommer comme il eust voulu...

and that Opinion passed currant till the beginning of this Age

and had not the Learned with these pretended Planets made their Court before to most of the Princes in Europe, giving the name of this Prince to one, and of that Prince to another Planet; I believe they would have quarrel'd who should be Master of these spots, that they might have nam'd them as they pleas'd.
explanations: The translation adds the clause "and receives several alterations by the way," introducing a scientific concept of light being modified during its interplanetary transmission. This idea is not present in Fontenelle's original text, which states only that planets reflect or send back the light received from the sun. This addition subtly inserts unoriginal scientific speculation.

The French phrase "pour ainsi dire" (so to speak) is used by Fontenelle to qualify the idea of planets making "exchanges" of light ("des échanges entre elles"). In the translation, this specific qualification is omitted from the discussion of planets. Instead, a similar parenthetical phrase, "(if I may so say,)", appears later, qualifying the description of light patterns as "the Richest Tissu's in the World." This relocation and reapplication of the authorial hedge shifts the focus of Fontenelle's slight rhetorical modesty from a scientific analogy to an elaborate poetic description, thereby subtly altering the narrator's emphasis and tone.

The French "Aussi" in this context functions as a consequential conjunction (equivalent to "Therefore" or "Thus"), implying that the Sun's central placement is a logical result of its role in distributing light. The English translation "likewise" primarily means "also" or "in the same manner," which fails to convey this causal link. This change weakens the logical structure of Fontenelle's argument for the Sun's central position.

The original French "On est bien embarrassé à le dire" (One is very much at a loss to say / It's very perplexing to say) uses an impersonal construction to describe a general scientific bewilderment. The translation "has often puzled better heads than mine" transforms this into a personal, self-deprecating comment by the narrator. This alters the narrator's persona from an objective conveyor of scientific thought to a more subjectively modest individual, subtly changing the tone and perceived authority of the speaker.

The French "on s'en desabusa" (one was disabused of it / one realized it was wrong) emphasizes a correction or disillusionment with a prior belief, highlighting the process of recognizing error in scientific progress. The English translation "and that Opinion passed currant till..." presents a more neutral and passive transition of thought, merely stating the opinion's duration. This lessens the emphasis on the critical process of abandoning incorrect ideas, subtly altering the portrayal of scientific advancement.

The translation significantly condenses Fontenelle's explanation for why sunspots were initially mistaken for planets. It omits the crucial context that "the entire philosophical world had its mind filled with nothing else [but new planets], and that, finally, new planets had come into fashion" ("que tout le Monde Philosophe n'avoit l'esprit remply d'autre chose, & qu'enfin les nouvelles Planetes s'estoient mises à la mode"). This omission removes Fontenelle's subtle critique of how scientific fads and collective enthusiasm influenced hasty judgments, thereby manipulating the reader's understanding of the described historical scientific reasoning.

The French "Déja les Sçavans faisoient leur Cour... & peut-estre il y auroit eu querelle..." (Already the Scholars were making their Court... and perhaps there would have been a quarrel...) states a fact, followed by a loosely connected speculation. The English translation "and had not the Learned... made their Court... I believe they would have quarrel'd..." reframes this into a counterfactual conditional statement. This implies that their act of "making court" (naming for princes) was a condition that affected whether a quarrel would happen (e.g., it prevented it or was an alternative to it). This alters the logical relationship between the scholars' actions and their potential for squabbling, subtly changing Fontenelle's sarcastic observation on scientific practices. Additionally, the introduction of "I believe" personalizes the narrator's speculation, contrasting with the impersonal French "il y auroit eu".

chunks.source_manual: <P062>Je ne trouve point cela bon, interrompit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>. Vous me disiez l'autre jour qu'on avoit donné aux differentes parties de la Lune des noms de Sçavans & d'Astronomes, & j'en estois fort contente. Puis que les Princes prennent pour eux la Terre, il est juste que les Sçavans se reservent le Ciel, & y dominent, mais ils n'en devroient point permettre l'entrée à d'autres. Souffrez, répondis-je, <UP></UP> qu'ils puissent, du moins en cas de besoin, engager aux Princes quelque Astre, ou quelque partie de la Lune. Quant aux taches du Soleil, ils n'en purent faire aucun usage. Il se trouva que ce n'estoient point des Planetes, mais des nuages, des fumées, des écumes, qui s'élèvent sur le Soleil. Elles sont tantost en grande quantité, tantost en petit nombre; tantost elles disparoissent toutes, quelquefois elles se mettent plusieurs ensemble, quelquefois elles se separent, quelquefois elles sont plus claires, quelquefois plus noires. Il y a des temps où l'on en voit beaucoup, il y en a d'autres, & mesme assez longs, où il n'en paroist aucune. Il semble que le Soleil soit une matiere liquide, quelques-uns disent de l'Or fondu, qui boüillonne incessamment <NCP></NCP>, & produit des impuretez, qui par la force de son mouvement sont rejettées sur sa surface. Elles s'y consument, & puis il s'en produit d'autres. Imaginez-vous quels Corps étrangers ce sont là. Il y en a tel qui est peut-estre aussi grand que la Terre. Jugez par là quelle est la quantité de cet Or fondu, ou l'étenduë de cette grande Mer de lumiere & de feu qu'on appelle le Soleil. D'autres disent que le Soleil paroît avec des Lunettes tout plein de Montagnes qui vomissent des flâmes, & que c'est comme un million de Monts Etna mis ensemble, mais on dit aussi que ces Montagnes sont une pure vision, causée par quelque chose qui arrive dans les Lunettes. Aquoy se fiera-t-on, s'il faut se défier des Lunettes mesme, ausquelles nous devons la connoissance de tant de nouveaux objects. Enfin, quoy que ce puisse estre que le Soleil, il ne paroist nullement propre à estre habité. C'est pourtant dommage, l'habitation seroit belle. On seroit au centre de tout, on verroit toutes les Planetes tourner regulierement autour de soy, au lieu que nous voyons dans leur cours une infinité de bizareries, qui n'y paroissent que parce que nous ne sommes pas en le lieu propre pour en bien juger, c'est à dire, au centre de leur mouvement. Cela n'est-il pas pitoyable? Il n'y a qu'un lieu dans le Monde, d'où l'étude des Astres puisse estre extremément facile, & justement dans ce lieu-là, il n'y a personne. Vous n'y songez pas, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>. Qui seroit dans le Soleil, verroit rien, ny Planetes, ny Etoiles Fixes. Le Soleil n'efface-t-il pas tout? Ce seroient ses Habitans qui seroient bien fondez à se croire seuls dans toute la Nature.</P062>
chunks.target_manual: <P051>'Twas but t'other day, says the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, you were describing the Moon, and call'd several places by the names of the most famous Astronomers. I was pleased with the fancy; for since the Princes have seiz'd on the Earth; 'tis fit the Philosophers should reserve the Heavens for themselves without any Competitors. Oh! trouble not your self, said I, <UP>the Philosophers make the best advantage of their Territories; and if they part with the least Star, 'tis on very good terms; let me tell you, an Acre of Land in England, is worth ten thousand in the Moon, but the spots on the Sun are fallen to nothing; the actions of Pensilvania are not half so low</UP>, 'tis now discover'd that they are not Planets, but Clouds, Steams, or Dross, which rise upon the Sun, sometimes in great quantity, sometimes in less; sometimes they are dark, sometimes clear, sometimes they continue a great while, and sometimes they disappear as long. It seems the Sun is a Liquid Matter, some think of melted Gold, which boils over <NCP>(as it were)</NCP> continually, and by the force of its motion casts the Scum or dross on its surface, where it is consumed, and others arise. Imagine then what strange Bodies these are, when some of 'em are as big as the Earth; What a vast quantity must there be of this melted Gold, and what must be the extent of this great Sea of Light and Fire which they call the Sun? Others say, the Sun appears through their Tellescopes, full of Mountains which vomit Fire continually, and are joyn'd together like millions of Etna's. Yet there are those who say these burning Mountains are pure Vision, caus'd by a fault in the Spectacles; but what shall we trust, if we must distrust our Tellescopes to which we owe the knowledge of so many new Objects? But let the Sun be what it will, it cannot be at all proper for habitation; and what pity 'tis not, for how pleasant would it be? You might then be at the Centre of the Universe, where you would see all the Planets turn regularly about you; but now we know nothing but extravagant Page 103 fancies, because we do not stand in the proper place; there is but one place in the World where the study or knowledge of the Stars is easily obtain'd, and what pity 'tis there is no body there. You forget your self sure, says she, were you in the Sun you would see nothing, neither Planets nor fix'd Stars, doth not the Sun efface all? so that could there be any Inhabitants there, they might justly think themselves the only people in Nature.</P051>

Yet there are those who say these burning Mountains are pure Vision, caus'd by a fault in the Spectacles;

explanations: The Marquise's strong statement in French that scholars ("Sçavans") should "dominent" (dominate) the heavens and actively "n'en devroient point permettre l'entrée à d'autres" (should not permit entry to others) is significantly softened. "Dominent" becomes the more passive "reserve for themselves," and the active, prohibitive gatekeeping is replaced by the less forceful state of being "without any Competitors." This alteration changes the portrayal of the Marquise's view on scholars' territoriality, making her sound less assertive and possessive. The shift from "Sçavans" (scholars/scientists) to "Philosophers" also subtly alters the basis of their claim from empirical to general intellectual authority.

The original French has the philosopher make an abstract, possibly ironic, statement about scholars hypothetically "pledging" celestial bodies to princes. The English translation entirely replaces this. It first changes the tone with "Oh! trouble not your self...make the best advantage...on very good terms," and then adds a specific economic comparison: "let me tell you, an Acre of Land in England, is worth ten thousand in the Moon,". This addition is a significant manipulation, introducing a nationalistic and commercial perspective entirely absent from Fontenelle's original text, aligning the philosopher's discourse with contemporary English concerns and values.

Fontenelle's text simply states that scholars could make no use of sunspots ("ils n'en purent faire aucun usage"). The English translation, after rendering this as "are fallen to nothing," appends a highly specific and topical financial analogy: "the actions of Pensilvania are not half so low," referring to the stock/share prices related to the Pennsylvania colony. This insertion manipulates the original by grounding the discussion in contemporary English colonial and economic affairs, changing Fontenelle's universal popular science tone to something more parochial and specific to an English audience of the late 17th/early 18th century.

The French "qui boüillonne incessamment" (which boils incessantly/continuously) is translated as "which boils over (as it werewolf) continually". The insertion of "(as it werewolf)" is a significant error that manipulates the reader's understanding. If interpreted as written, it introduces a nonsensical and bizarre image into a scientific description, potentially confusing the reader or trivializing the text. This error, whether a typo for "as it were" or a more profound mistake, distorts the original meaning by adding an absurd element.

The original French "causée par quelque chose qui arrive dans les Lunettes" (caused by something that happens/occurs in the lenses/telescopes) offers a more vague and neutral explanation for the "pure vision." The English translation "caus'd by a fault in the Spectacles" attributes the phenomenon explicitly to an instrumental defect or error. This shift from a general, unspecified occurrence to a specific "fault" subtly manipulates the reader by guiding them towards a more critical view of early telescopic observations, suggesting inherent unreliability in the technology itself.

The French "une infinité de bizareries" (an infinity of oddities/irregularities) is translated as "extravagant Page 103 fancies." Ignoring the likely intrusive "Page 103" (which must be included per instructions), the phrase "extravagant fancies" significantly intensifies the negativity compared to "bizareries," portraying the geocentric view as almost delusional rather than merely complex due to perspective. Crucially, the translation omits the explanatory clause "c'est à dire, au centre de leur mouvement" (that is to say, at the center of their movement), which clarifies Fontenelle's Copernican argument about why Earth is not the ideal vantage point. This omission manipulates the reader's understanding by simplifying and weakening the scientific reasoning presented.

chunks.source_manual: <P063>J'avoüe que je m'estois trompé, répondis-je, je ne songeois qu'à la situation où est le Soleil,& non à l'effet de sa lumiere; mais vous qui me redressez si à propos, vous voulez bien que je vous dise que vous vous estes trompée aussi; les Habitans du Soleil ne le verroient seulement pas. Ou ils ne pourroient soûtenir la force de sa lumiere, ou ils ne la pourroient recevoir, faute d'en estre à quelque distance, & tout bien considéré, le Soleil ne seroit qu'un séjour d'Aveugles; encore un coup, il n'est pas fait pour estre habité; mais voulez-vous que nous poursuivions nostre Voyage des Mondes? Nous sommes arrivéz au centre qui est toûjours le lieu le plus bas dans tout ce qui est rond, il faudroit presentement retourner sur nos pas, & remonter. Nous retrouverons Mercure, Venus, la Terre, la Lune, toutes Planetes que nous avons visitées. Ensuite c'est Mars qui se presente. Mars n'a rien de curieux que je sçache, ses jours ne sont pas d'une heure entiere plus longs que les nostres; ses années valent deux de nos années. Il est plus petit que la Terre, il voit le Soleil un peu moins grand & moins vif que nous ne le voyons; enfin Mars ne vaut pas trop la peine qu'on s'y arreste. Mais la jolie chose que Jupiter avec ses quatre Lunes ou <RW>Satellites</RW>! Ce sont quatre petites Planetes qui tournent autour de luy, comme nostre Lune tourne autour de nous. Mais, interrompit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, pourquoy y a-t-il des Planetes qui tournent autour d'autres Planetes qui ne valent pas mieux qu'elles? Serieusement il me paroîtroit plus regulier & plus uniforme que toutes les Planetes, grandes & petites, n'eussent que le mesme mouvement autour du Soleil!</P063>
chunks.target_manual: <P052>I own said I, my mistake; I was thinking of the Situation of the Sun, and not of the effect of its Light: I thank you for your correction, but must take the boldness to tell you, that you are in an errour, as well as my self; for were there Inhabitants in the Sun, they would not see at all, either they could not bear the strength of its light, or for want of a due distance, they could not receive it; so that things well consider'd, all the People there must be stark blind, which is another reason why the Sun cannot be inhabited; but let us pursue our Voyage. We are now arriv'd at the Centre, which is always the bottom, or lowest place of what is round; if we go on, we must ascend; we shall find Mercury, Venus, the Earth, the Moon, all the Planets we have already visited; the next is Mars: Mars hath nothing curious that I know of, his Day is not quite an hour longer than ours, but his Year is twice as much as our Year; he is a little less than the Earth; and the Sun seems not altogether so large and so bright to him, as it appears to us? but let us leave Mars, he is not worth our stay: But what a pretty thing is Jupiter, with his four Moons, <UP>or Yeomen of the Guard</UP>; they are four little Planets that turn round him, as our Moon turns round us. But why, says she, interrupting me, must there be Planets to turn round other Planets, that are no better than themselves? I should think it would be more regular and uniform, that all the Planets, little and great, without any distinction, should have one and the same motion round the Sun.</P052>

encore un coup, il n'est pas fait pour estre habité

ses quatre Lunes ou Satellites!
target_segments: all the People there must be stark blind
which is another reason why the Sun cannot be inhabited
but let us pursue our Voyage.

explanations: The original French 'le Soleil ne seroit qu'un séjour d'Aveugles' (the Sun would only be an abode of Blind people) focuses on the Sun as a place and uses a conditional, more speculative tone. The translation shifts focus to the inhabitants ('all the People there'), asserts their condition with more certainty ('must be'), and intensifies it ('stark blind'). This changes the original's more detached observation about the environment to a more dramatic and certain declaration about its hypothetical inhabitants.

The French 'encore un coup, il n'est pas fait pour estre habité' (furthermore/in short, it is not made/designed to be inhabited) presents a concluding thought with a nuance of purpose or design. The translation 'which is another reason why the Sun cannot be inhabited' changes the logical connector to make it a direct consequence of the previous point (blindness) and alters 'n'est pas fait pour' to 'cannot be,' shifting the meaning from a lack of intended purpose to a simple lack of possibility, thereby losing a subtle philosophical layer of the original.

The original French 'voulez-vous que nous poursuivions' is a polite interrogative ('do you want us to pursue...?'), seeking the Marquise's agreement. The English translation 'let us pursue' changes this to an imperative statement, making the philosopher more directive and less overtly courteous. This subtly alters the power dynamic and the portrayal of the philosopher's interaction with the Marquise, potentially diminishing the respectful tone Fontenelle established.

The French 'Satellites' is a neutral, scientific term for Jupiter's moons. The English translation augments 'Moons' with 'or Yeomen of the Guard,' a culturally specific British reference to the monarch's bodyguards. This domestication introduces a nationalistic and somewhat whimsical image not present in the original, altering the tone from scientific popularization and potentially shifting the reader's perception by associating astronomical bodies with a familiar, non-scientific institution.

chunks.source_manual: <P064>Ah! Madame, répliquay-je! Si vous sçaviez ce que c'est que les <RW><NCP>Tourbillons</NCP></RW> de Descartes, ces Tourbillons dont le nom est si terrible, & l'idée si agreable, vous ne parleriez pas comme vous faites. La teste me dust-elle tourner, dit-elle en riant, il est beau de sçavoir ce que c'est que les Tourbillons. Achevez de me rendre folle, je ne me ménage plus, je ne connois plus de retenuë sur la Philosophie; laissons parler le monde, & donnons-nous aux Tourbillons. Je ne vous connoissois pas de pareils emportemens, répris-je; c'est dommage qu'ils n'ayent que les Tourbillons pour objet. Ce qu'on appelle un Tourbillon, c'est un amas de matiere dont les parties sont détachées les unes des autres, & se meuvent toutes en un mesme sens; permis à elles d'avoir pendant ce temps-là quelques petites mouvemens particuliers, pourveu qu'elles suivent toûjours le mouvement general. Ainsi un Tourbillon de vent <UP></UP>, c'est une infinité de petites parties d'air, qui tournent en rond toutes ensemble, & enveloppent ce qu'elles rencontrent. Vous sçavez que les Planetes sont portées dans la matiere celeste, qui est d'une subtilité, & d'une agitation prodigieuse. Tout ce grand amas de matiere celeste, qui est depuis le Soleil <UP></UP>jusqu'aux Etoiles fixes, tourne en rond, & emportant avec soy les Planetes <UP></UP>, les fait tourner toutes en un mesme sens autour du Soleil, qui occupe le centre; mais en des temps plus ou moins longs, selon qu'elles en sont plus ou moins éloignées. Il n'y a pas jusqu'au Soleil qui ne tourne; mais il ne tourne que sur luy-mesme, parce qu'il est justement au milieu de toute cette <IIM>matiere celeste</IIM>; & vous remarquerez en passant, que quand la Terre seroit dans la place où il est, elle ne pourroit encore faire moins que de tourner sur elle-mesme.</P064> <P065>Voila quel est le grand Tourbillon dont le Soleil est comme le Maistre; mais en mesme temps les Planetes se composent de petits Tourbillons particuliers à l'imitation de celuy du Soleil. Chacune d'elles en tournant autour du Soleil, ne laisse pas de tourner autour d'elle-mesme, & fait tourner aussi autour d'elle en mesme sens une certaine quantité de cette matiere celeste, qui est toûjours preste à suivre tous les mouvemens qu'on luy veut donner, s'ils ne la détournent pas de son mouvement general. c'est-là le Tourbillon particulier de la Planete & elle le pousse aussi loin que la force de son mouvement se peut étendre. S'il faut qu'il tombe dans ce petit Tourbillon quelque Planete moindre que celle qui y domine, la voilà emportée par la grande, & forcée indispensablement à tourner autour d'elle, & le tout ensemble, la grande Planete, la petite, & le Tourbillon qui les renferme, n'en tourne pas moins autour du Soleil. C'est ainsi qu'au commencement du Monde nous nous fismes suivre par la Lune, parce qu'elle se trouva dans l'étenduë de nostre Tourbillon, & tout à fait à nostre bienséance. Jupiter dont je commençois à vous parler, fut plus heureux ou plus puissant que nous. Il y avoit dans son voisinage quatre petites Planetes, ils se les assujettit toutes quatre, & <UP></UP> nous qui sommes une Planete principale, croyez-vous que nous l'eussions esté, si nous nous fussions trouvés proches de luy? Il est quatre-vingt-dix fois plus gros que nous, il nous auroit engloutis sans peine dans son Tourbillon, & nous ne serions qu'une Lune de sa dépendance, au lieu que nous en avons une qui est dans la nostre, tant il est vray que le seul hazard de la situation décide souvent de toute la fortune qu'on doit avoir.</P065>
chunks.target_manual: <P053>Ah, Madam, said I, if you knew what were Descartes's <RW>Whirlpools or Vortex's</RW>, <NCP>(whose Name is terrible, but their Idea pleasant)</NCP> you would not talk as you do. Must my Head, says she, smiling, turn round to comprehend 'em, or must I become a perfect Fool to understand the misteries of Philosophy? Well, let the World say what it will, go on with your Whirlpools. I will, said I, and you shall see the Whirlpools are worthy of these transports: That then which we call a Whirlpool, or Vortex, is a Mass of Matter, whose parts are separated or detach'd one from another, yet have all one uniform motion, and at the same time, every one is allow'd, or has a particular Motion of its own, provided if follows the general Motion: Thus a Vortex of Wind, or Whirlwind, is an infinity of little particles of Air, which turn round all together, and involve what ever they meet with. You know the Planets are born up by the Celestial Matter, which is prodigiously subtile and active; so that this great Mass, or <IIM>Ocean of</IIM> Celestial Matter, which flows as far as from the Sun to the fix'd Stars, turns round, and bears the Planets along with it, making them all turn after the same manner round the Sun, who possesses the Centre, but in a longer or shorter time, according as they are farther or nearer in distance to it; there is nothing to the very Sun, which does not turn, but he turns on himself because he is just in the middle of this Celestial Matter; and you must know by the way, that were the Earth in his place, it must turn on it self, as the Sun does. This is the great Vortex, of which the Sun is Lord; yet at the same time, the Planets make little particular Vortex's, in imitation of that of the Sun, each of 'em in turning round the Sun, doth at the same time turn round it self, and makes a certain quantity of Celestial Matter turn round it likewise, which is always prepar'd to follow the Motion the Planet gives it, provided it is not diverted from its general Motion; this then is the particular Vortex of the Planet, which pushes it as far as the strength of its Motion reaches; and if by chance, a lesser Planet falls into the Vortex of a greater Planet, it is immediately born away by the greater, and is indispensably forc'd to turn round it, tho' at the same time, the great Planet, the little Planet, and the Vortex which encloses 'em, all turn round the Sun: 'Twas thus at the beginning of the World, when we made the Moon follow us, because she was within the reach of our Vortex, and therefore wholly at our dispose: Jupiter was stronger, or more fortunate than we, he had four little Planets in his neighbourhood, and he brought 'em all four under his subjection; and <UP>no doubt</UP>, we, tho' a principal Planet, had had the same Fate, had we been within the Sphere of his Activity; he is ninety times bigger than the Earth, and would certainly have swallow'd us into his Vortex; we had then been no more than a Moon in his Family, when now we have one to wait on us; so that you see the advantage of Situation, decides often all our good Fortune.</P053>

explanations: The Marquise's enthusiastic embrace of philosophy ('Go on, drive me completely mad [with it], I no longer hold back, I know no more restraint regarding Philosophy') is altered. The translation reframes this as a somewhat self-deprecating question about needing to become 'a perfect Fool' and introduces 'misteries of Philosophy.' This subtly changes her tone from confident eagerness to one that questions her own capacity or implies that philosophy is inherently mystifying, potentially diminishing the portrayal of a woman engaging boldly with new scientific ideas.

The philosopher's original witty and slightly flirtatious remark ('I didn't know you had such passions; it's a shame they are only for Vortices') is entirely omitted and replaced. This substitution removes a key element of the sophisticated, playful dynamic between the characters, simplifying the philosopher's persona and the literary charm of the dialogue by making his response more straightforwardly didactic rather than socially nuanced.

The French 'Maistre' (Master), softened by 'comme' (as/like), is translated as the more authoritative 'Lord,' and 'comme' is omitted. In the 17th-century English socio-religious context, 'Lord' carried stronger connotations of sovereignty, potentially aligning the Sun's role with more traditional hierarchical or even quasi-divine authority, subtly shifting from Fontenelle's more functional description of the Sun as a central governor in a mechanistic system.

The original text's engaging rhetorical question to the Marquise ('do you believe we would have been [subjected]... if we had found ourselves near him?') is transformed into a definitive assertion ('and no doubt... had had the same Fate'). This change removes the interactive, speculative element of the dialogue, making the philosopher's tone more dogmatic. Additionally, the simple 'proches de luy' (near him) becomes the more formal 'within the Sphere of his Activity,' altering the conversational style to a more technical one.

The original 'une Lune de sa dépendance' (a moon under its control) and 'une qui est dans la nostre' (one under our control) describe a power dynamic. The translation shifts this to 'a Moon in his Family' and 'one to wait on us.' 'In his Family' sentimentalizes the subservience, while 'to wait on us' introduces a distinct connotation of servitude and domestic hierarchy not explicit in the French. This anthropomorphizes the celestial relationship and could reinforce an Earth-centric view of cosmic hierarchy in social terms.

The French 'le seul hazard de la situation' highlights 'chance' or 'randomness' ('hazard') as the key factor. By translating 'hazard' as 'advantage,' the translation fundamentally alters the philosophical implication. Instead of fortune being contingent on mere chance of placement, as Fontenelle suggests, it is presented as resulting from an inherent 'advantage' of the situation, thereby shifting the meaning from a concept of cosmic luck to one of inherent benefit or a more ordered, less random universe.

chunks.source_manual: <P066>Et qui nous assure, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, que nous demeurerons toûjours où nous sommes? Je commence à craindre que nous ne fassions la folie de nous approcher d'une Planete aussi entreprenante que Jupiter, ou qu'il <IIM>ne vienne</IIM> vers nous pour nous absorber; car il me paroist que dans ce grand mouvement, où vous dites qu'est la matiere Celeste, elle devroit agiter les Planetes irregulierement, tantost les approcher, tantost les éloigner les unes des autres. <UP>Nous pourrions aussi-tost y gagner qu'y perdre, répondis-je</UP>, peut-estre irions-nous soumettre à nostre domination Mercure & Venus, qui sont de petites Planetes, & qui ne nous pourroient résister. Mais nous n'avons rien à esperer ny à craindre; les Planetes se tiennent où elles sont, & les nouvelles conquestes leur sont défenduës, comme elles l'étoient autrefois aux Rois de la Chine. Vous sçavez bien que quand on met de l'huile avec de l'eau, l'huile surnage. Qu'on mette sur ces deux liqueurs un Corps extremement leger <UP></UP>, l'huile le soûtiendra, & il n'ira pas jusqu'à l'eau. Qu'on y mette un autre Corps plus pesant, & qui soit justement d'une certaine pesanteur, il passera au travers de l'huile, qui sera trop foible pour l'arrester, & tombera jusqu'à ce qu'il rencontre l'eau, qui aura la force de le soûtenir. Ainsi dans cette liqueur composée de deux liqueurs qui ne se mêlent point, deux Corps inégalement pesants se mettent naturellement à deux places differentes, & jamais l'un ne montera, ny l'autre ne descendra. Qu'on mette encore d'autres liqueurs qui se tiennent separées, & qu'on y plonge d'autres corps, il arrivera la mesme chose. Representez-vous que la Matiere Celeste qui remplit ce grand Tourbillon, à differentes couches qui s'envelopent les unes les autres, & dont les pesanteurs sont differentes, comme celles de l'huile & de l'eau, & des autres liqueurs. Les Planetes ont aussi differentes pesanteurs; chacune d'elles par consequent s'arreste dans la couche qui a précisément la force necessaire pour la soûtenir, & qui luy fait équilibre, & vous voyez bien qu'il n'est pas possible qu'elle en sorte jamais.</P066>
chunks.target_manual: <P054>But pray, says she, who can assure us we shall still continue as we do now? if we should be such Fools as to go near Jupiter, or he so <IIM>ambitious</IIM> as to approach us, what will become of us? for if (as you say) the Celestial Matter is continually under this great Motion, it must needs agitate the Planets irregularly; sometimes drive 'em together, and sometimes separate 'em. <UP>Luck is all, said I; we may win as well as lose</UP>, and who knows, but we should bring Mercury and Venus under our Government; they are little Planets, and cannot resist us; but in this particular, Madam, we need not hope or fear; the Planets keep within their own bounds, and are oblig'd (as formerly the Kings of China were) not to undertake new Conquests. Have you not seen when you put Water and Oyl together, the Oyl swims a top; and if to these two Liquors, you add a very light Liquor, the Oyl bears it up, and it will not sink to the Water: But put an heavier Liquor, of a just weight, and it will pass through the Oyl, which is too weak to sustain it, and sink till it comes to the Water, which is strong enough to bear it up; so that in this Liquor, compos'd of two Liquors, which do not mingle, two Bodies of an unequal weight, will naturally assume two different Places; the one will never ascend, the other will never descend: Fancy then that the Celestial Matter which fills this great Vortex, hath several resting places, one by another, whose weight are different, like that of Oyl, Water, and other Liquors; the Planets too are of a different weight, and consequently, every Planet settles in that place which has a just strength to sustain and keep it equilibrate, so you see 'tis impossible it should ever go beyond.</P054>

explanations: The original "la folie de nous approcher" (the folly of approaching) describes a potential foolish action. The translation "if we should be such Fools as to go near" changes this into a direct characterization of the people involved ("such Fools"), making the Marquise's statement more pejorative and altering the tone from concern about a misguided act to a judgment of persona.

The original French states a potential consequence of Jupiter approaching: "pour nous absorber" (to absorb us). The translation replaces this direct consequence with the anxious, rhetorical question "what will become of us?". This is an addition by the translator that heightens the Marquise's expressed alarm and shifts the focus from the event itself to her emotional reaction.

The word "continually" is added in the translation ("the Celestial Matter is continually under this great Motion") to describe the motion of Celestial Matter. The original French ("où vous dites qu'est la matiere Celeste" - where you say the Celestial matter is) does not contain such an adverbial intensifier, thus the translation subtly alters the description by emphasizing unceasing movement not explicit in the source.

The French "elle devroit agiter" (it ought to/should agitate) expresses a logical deduction with a degree of conjecture or expectation. The translation "it must needs agitate" is significantly stronger, implying a more certain and unavoidable consequence. This shifts the portrayal of the Marquise's reasoning, making it sound more definitive than the original's more tentative "devroit."

The French phrase "car il me paroist que" (for it appears to me that) introduces the Marquise's subsequent thought as her own observation or understanding. The translation "for if (as you say)" reframes it as a condition dependent on the philosopher's prior statements, subtly shifting the agency of the thought from the Marquise's direct perception to a consequence derived from the philosopher's assertion.

The idiomatic phrase "Luck is all" is an addition by the translator at the beginning of the philosopher's response. The original French "Nous pourrions aussi-tost y gagner qu'y perdre" (We could as easily gain as lose by it) is a neutral statement of equal probability. "Luck is all" introduces a colloquial and somewhat fatalistic tone to the philosopher's speech, which is not present in the original.

The source "un Corps extremement leger" (an extremely light Body/Object) is mistranslated as "a very light Liquor". This fundamentally alters Fontenelle's scientific analogy, which involves solid bodies of different densities finding their equilibrium in layered liquids, not additional different liquids. This misrepresentation manipulates the reader's understanding of the physical principle being explained.

Consistent with the previous error, "un autre Corps plus pesant" (another heavier Body/Object) is again mistranslated as "an heavier Liquor". This reinforces the incorrect alteration of Fontenelle's analogy by substituting liquids for solid objects, systematically misleading the reader about the scientific demonstration of how planets (bodies) maintain their orbits.

The French sentence "Qu'on mette encore d'autres liqueurs qui se tiennent separées, & qu'on y plonge d'autres corps, il arrivera la mesme chose." is omitted in the translation. In the original, this sentence follows the two-layer/two-body example and precedes the direct application of the analogy to celestial matter. Its omission, indicated in the target text between '...the other will never descend:' and 'Fancy then that...', removes a pedagogical step by Fontenelle designed to extend the analogy to multiple layers and bodies. This simplification streamlines the argument but potentially weakens the reader's grasp of its generalizability before applying it to the cosmos.

The translation of "differentes couches qui s'envelopent les unes les autres" (different layers that envelop/wrap around one another) as "several resting places, one by another" changes the descriptive imagery. "Couches qui s'envelopent" evokes a dynamic, structured medium of distinct, enveloping strata, crucial for the density-based analogy. "Resting places" presents a more static and less specific image, subtly altering the reader's conceptualization of the "Matiere Celeste" (Celestial Matter).

The translation of "couche" (layer) to "place" in the phrase "s'arreste dans la couche" (settles in the layer) becoming "settles in that place" reinforces the earlier shift from "layers" to "places". This consistently alters the imagery of Fontenelle's analogy from a structured medium of layers to more ambiguous "places," potentially weakening the reader's understanding of the density-based stratification essential to the argument.

chunks.source_manual: <P067>Je conçois, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, que ces pesanteurs-là reglent fort bien les rangs. Plust à Dieu qu'il y eust quelque chose de pareil qui les reglast parmi nous, & qui fixast les Gens dans les places qui leur sont naturellement convenables. Me voila fort en repos du costé de Jupiter. Je suis bien-aise qu'il nous laisse dans nostre petit Tourbillon <SC>avec nostre Lune unique</SC>. Je suis d'humeur à me borner aisément, & je ne luy envie point les quatre qu'il a.</P067> <P068>Vous auriez tort de les luy envier, repris-je, il n'en a point plus qu'il ne luy en faut. Dans l'éloignement où il est du Soleil, les Lunes ne reçoivent & ne luy renvoyent, qu'une lumiere assez faible. Il est vray que comme il tourne sur luy-mesme en dix heures, & que ses nuits, qui par consequent <IIM>n'en durent que cinq</IIM>, sont fort courtes, quatre Lunes ne paroîtroient pas si necessaires, mais il y a autre chose à considerer. Icy sous les Pôles, on a six mois de jour, & six mois de nuit. C'est que les Pôles sont les deux extremitez de la Terre les plus éloignées des lieux où le Soleil donne à plomb, & sur lesquels il paroit faire sa course. La Lune ne tient, ou paroist tenir la même route à peu prés que le Soleil, & si les Habitans des Pôles voyent le Soleil pendant toute une moitié de sa course d'un an, & pendant toute l'autre moitié ne le voyent point, ils voyent aussi la Lune pendant toute une moitié de sa course d'un mois, c'est à dire, pendant quinze jours, & ils ne la voyent point pendant toute l'autre moitié. <IIM>Les années de Jupiter</IIM> en valent douze des nostre, & il doit y avoir dans cette Planete deux extremitez opposées, où l'on ait des jours & des nuits de six ans entiers. <IIM>Des nuits</IIM> de six ans sont bien longues, aussi est ce principalement pour elles que je crois que les quatre Lunes sont faites. Celle qui à l'egard de Jupiter est la plus élevée, fait son cercle autour de luy en dix-sept jours, la seconde en sept, la troisiéme en trois jours & demy, la quatrième en quarante-deux heures. Leurs courses estant coupées justement par la moitié pour ces malheureux <UP></UP> Pays qui ont six ans de nuit, il ne se peut passer vingt & une heures, qu'on ne voye paroistre au moins la derniere Lune. C'est quelque consolation pendant des tenebres d'une durée si ennuyeuse; mais quelque lieu que l'on habite dans Jupiter, ces quatre Lunes vous y donnent les plus jolis Spectacles <UP></UP> du monde. Tantost elles se lèvent toutes quatre ensemble, & puis se separent selon l'inégalité de leur cours; tantost elles sont toutes à leur Midy rangées l'une au dessus de l'autre, tantost <RW>on les</RW> voit toutes quatre sur l'Horizon à des distances égales; tantost quand deux se levent, deux autres se couchent; sur tout j'aimerois à voir ce jeu perpetuel d'Eclipses qu'elles font, car il ne se passe point de jour qu'elles ne s'éclipsent les unes les autres, ou qu'elles n'éclipsent le Soleil, & asseurément les Eclipses s'estant renduës si familieres en ce Monde-là, elles y sont un sujet de divertissement, & non pas de frayeur, comme en celuy-ci.</P068> <P069><SC>Gens de nostre Lune</SC>, me fait douter que Jupiter en ait beaucoup sur le Habitans de siennes, & je croy qu'un des avantages ausquels ils puissent le plus raisonnablemént pretendre, c'est de leur faire peur. <UP>Par exemple, dans celle qui est la plus proche de luy, ils le voyent trois cents soixante fois plus gros que nostre Lune ne nous paroist, car il la surpasse autant en grosseur. Il est, je croy, beaucoup plus proche d'eux, qu'elle n'est de nous, sa grosseur en augmente encore. Ils fent comme des Colonies de Jupiter; qu'elles eussent receu de luy, s'il estoit possible, leurs Loix & leurs Coûtumes; que par consequent elles luy redissent quelque sorte d'hommage, & ne regardassent la grande Planete qu'avec respect. Ne faudroit-il point aussi, luy dis-je, que les quatre Lunes envoyassent de temps en temps des Députez dans Jupiter, pour luy prester ferment de fidelité? Pour moy, je vous avoüe que le peu de superiorité que nous avons sur les Gens.</UP></P069>
chunks.target_manual: <P055>Would to God, says the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, our World were as well regulated, and every one among us knew their proper Place. I am now in no fear of being over-run by Jupiter; and since he lets us alone in our Vortex, with our Moon, I do not envy him the four which he hath. Did you envy him, I reply'd, you would do him wrong, for he has no more than what he has occasion for; at the distance he is from the Sun, his Moons receive, and send him but a very weak light; it is true, that as he turns upon himself in ten hours, his nights, by consequence, are but five hours long; so one would think there is no great occasion for four Moons; but there are other things to be considered. Here under the Poles, they have six Months Day, and six Months Night, because the Poles are the two extremities of the Earth, the farthest removed from those places where the Sun is over 'em in a perpendicular line. The Moon seems to keep almost the same course as the Sun, and if the Inhabitants of the Poles see the Sun during one half of his course of a Year, and during the other half, do not see him at all; they see the Moon likewise during one half of her course of a Month; that is, she appears to 'em fifteen days, but they do not see her during the other half. Jupiter's Year is as much as twelve of ours, so that there must be two opposite extremities in that Planet, where their Night and their Day are six Years each. A Night six Years long, is a little disconsolate, and 'tis for that reason, I suppose, they have four Moons; that which (in regard to Jupiter) is uppermost, finisheth its course about him in seventeen days, the second in seven, the third in three days and an half, and the fourth in two and forty hours; and tho' they are so unfortunate as to have six years Night, yet their course being exactly divided into halves, they never pass above one and twenty hours, wherein they do not see at least the last Moon, which is a great comfort in so tedious a darkness; so that be where you will, these four Moons are sometimes the prettiest sight imaginable; sometimes they rise all four together, and then separate according to the inequality of their course; sometimes they are all in their Meridian, rang'd one above another, sometimes you see 'em at equal distances on the Horizon, sometimes when two rise, the other two go down. Oh, how I should love to see this pleasant sport of Eclipses; for there is not a Day passes but they Eclipse the Sun, or one another; and they are so accustom'd to this diversion in Jupiter, <UP>that the late Duke of B-m in his Rehersal, brought the dance of Eclipses from that Planet, as now most of our modish Dances come out of France</UP>.</P055>

explanations: The French title "Marquise," specific to French nobility and salon culture, is changed to the English "Countess." While an adaptive choice common in translations, "Countess" is not an exact equivalent in rank (Marquise/Marquis is generally higher than Comte/Countess). This domestication subtly alters the cultural specificity of the character, potentially shifting perception of her status or the work's original French setting.

The original French phrase "qui fixast les Gens dans les places qui leur sont naturellement convenables" (that would fix People in the places naturally suitable for them) suggests an external regulation guiding people to naturally suitable roles. The translation "every one among us knew their proper Place" shifts the emphasis to individuals' knowledge of a pre-ordained "proper Place." This subtly alters the meaning towards internalized social conformity and fixed stations, potentially resonating with contemporary English hierarchical social views rather than Fontenelle's idea of natural fitness.

The original French "Me voila fort en repos du costé de Jupiter" (Here I am, very much at ease/calm concerning Jupiter) is transformed into the more dramatic statement "I am now in no fear of being over-run by Jupiter". This introduces a notion of potential threat ("being over-run") that is not present in the original, thereby altering the tone from simple reassurance to relief from a posited danger, manipulating the reader's perception of the Countess's sentiment.

The initial clause of the French sentence, "Je suis d'humeur à me borner aisément" (I am of a temperament to be easily contented/to limit myself easily), is omitted in the English translation, which only renders the second clause "& je ne luy envie point les quatre qu'il a" (and I do not envy him the four he has). This omission removes the Marquise's stated personal philosophy of moderation, which underpins her lack of envy. This alters the reader's understanding of her character, making her statement seem less nuanced.

The French "une lumiere assez faible" (a rather/fairly weak light) is intensified in the translation to "a very weak light." This slight exaggeration alters the scientific description by making the light received by Jupiter's moons seem weaker than conveyed in the original text.

The French phrase "C'est quelque consolation" (It is some consolation) is amplified in the translation to "which is a great comfort." This change in degree significantly intensifies the emotional weight of the statement, making the original understated observation more emphatic and thus altering the tone.

The French "ces quatre Lunes vous y donnent les plus jolis Spectacles du monde" (these four Moons give you there the prettiest spectacles in the world) implies a general and consistent availability of these sights. The insertion of "sometimes" in the English translation ("these four Moons are sometimes the prettiest sight imaginable") inaccurately limits the frequency of these celestial spectacles, diminishing the sense of continuous wonder conveyed by Fontenelle.

The translator replaces Fontenelle's general philosophical reflection that familiarity with eclipses on Jupiter would make them a "sujet de divertissement, & non pas de frayeur, comme en celuy-ci" (a subject of entertainment there, & not of fear, as in this one [Earth]) with a specific, contemporary English cultural and satirical reference: "that the late Duke of B-m in his Rehersal, brought the dance of Eclipses from that Planet, as now most of our modish Dances come out of France." This is a significant manipulation, substituting the original's cross-cultural psychological observation with topical English social commentary, thereby altering the meaning, tone, and intellectual content of the passage and localizing it in a way that diverges from Fontenelle's broader Enlightenment aims.

chunks.source_manual: <P070>Et vous ne manquerez pas, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, à faire habiter ces quatre Lunes, quoy que ce ne foient que de petites Planetes subalternes, destinées seulement à en éclairer une autre pendant ces nuits? N'en doutez nullement, répondis-je. Ces Planetes n'en sont pas moins dignes d'estre habitées pour avoir le malheur d'estre asservies à tourner autour d'une autre plus importante.</P070> <P071>Je voudrais donc, reprit-elle, que les Habitans des quatre Lunes de Jupiter <UP></UP>, fussont donc toûjours cette monstrueuse Planete suspédüe sur leurs testes à une distance assez petite. En verité, si les Gaulois craignaient anciennement que le Ciel ne tombast sur eux, les Habitans de cette Lune auroient bien plus de sujet de craindre une chute de Jupiter <UP></UP>. C'est peut-estre là aussi la frayeur qu'ils ont, dit- elle, au lieu de celle des Eclipses, dont vous m'avez asseuré qu'ils sont exempts, & qu'il faut bien remplacer par quelque autre sottise? Il le faut de necessité absolüe, répondis-je. L'Inventeur du troisième Systême dont je vous parlois l'autre jour, le celebre Ticho-Brahé <UP></UP>, un des plus grands Astronomes qui furent jamais, n'avoit garde de craindre les Eclipses, comme le Vulgaire les craint, il passoit sa vie avec elles. Mais croiriez-vous bien ce qu'il craignoit en leur place? Si en sortant de son logis, la premiere personne qu'il rencontroit estoit une Vieille, si un Lievre traversoit son chemin, Ticho-Brahé croyoit que la journée devoit estre malheureuse, & retournoit promptement se renfermer chez luy, sans oser commencer la moindre chose.</P071>
chunks.target_manual: <P056>Well, says the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, I hope you will People these four Moons, tho' you say they are but little secondary Planets, appointed to give light to another Planet during its Night. Do not doubt it, I reply'd; these Planets are not a jot the worse to be inhabited, for being forc'd to turn round another Planet of greater consequence. I would have then, says she, the People of these four Moons, to be so many Colonies under Jupiter's <UP>Government</UP>; they should receive their Laws and Customs from him. Would it not be convenient too, said I, that they should send Deputies with Addresses to him; for he hath cetainly a more absolute command over his Moon, than we have over ours; tho' his Power <UP>after all, is but imaginary</UP>, and consists chiefly in making 'em afraid; for that Moon which is nearest to him, sees that he is <UP>three hundred and sixty times bigger than our Moon appears to us</UP>; for in truth, he is so much bigger than she; he is also much nearer to them, than our Moon is to us, the which makes him appear the greater, so that this <UP>formidable</UP> Planet hangs continually over their Heads, at a very little distance and if the Gauls were afraid heretofore that the Heavens would fall on 'em, I think the Inhabitants of that Moon may well be apprehensive that Jupiter will at some time or other overwhelm 'em. They are, says she, I fancy, possess'd with that fear, because they are not concern'd at Eclipses: Every one has their due folly; we are afraid of an Eclipse, and they, that Jupiter will fall on their Heads. It is very true, said I, the Inventer of the third Systeme, I told you t'other night, the famous Ticho Brahe, <NCP>(one of the greatest Astronomers that ever was,)</NCP> <UP>did not apprehend the least danger from an Eclipse, when every body else was under the greatest consternation; yet this great Man had as an unaccountable a fear, did a hare cross him, or were the first Person he met in a morning an old Woman, home presently went Ticho Brahe, he shut himself up for that day, and would not meddle with the least Business</UP>.</P056>

Every one has their due folly;
explanations: The original French text describes the Marquise's wish for the inhabitants of Jupiter's moons to constantly perceive the 'monstrous Planet suspended over their heads.' The translation fundamentally changes this idea into a political arrangement where these inhabitants are 'Colonies under Jupiter's Government' receiving 'Laws and Customs from him.' This shift introduces a socio-political dimension of colonial governance entirely absent from Fontenelle's original, thereby manipulating the reader's understanding of the Marquise's speculation and subtly infusing the text with themes resonant with late 17th-century English political realities and colonial activities.

The English translation inserts a substantial speech by the narrator that has no basis in the provided French source text. This inserted dialogue follows the (already altered) statement by the Marquise (whose original sentence ends with 'distance assez petite.') and elaborates on the introduced political theme (deputies, addresses, absolute command over moons) and adds specific astronomical details about Jupiter's appearance. This addition significantly manipulates the original by fabricating new content attributed to the philosopher-narrator, potentially to make the text resonate more with contemporary English discussions about governance, authority ('absolute command'), and scientific detail, thereby shifting the emphasis and content of Fontenelle's work.

In the French original, the Marquise poses a specific, somewhat pointed rhetorical question: whether the moon-dwellers' fear of Jupiter falling replaces their lack of fear of eclipses, characterizing this new fear as 'quelque autre sottise' (some other foolishness/nonsense). The English translation transforms this specific query into a general, proverbial maxim, 'Every one has their due folly.' This generalization changes the tone, making the Marquise's observation broader and more resigned, rather than a direct, critical comment on a specific superstition, thereby subtly altering her characterization and the directness of Fontenelle's critique of popular fears.

chunks.source_manual: <P072>Il ne seroit pas juste, <IIM>reprit-elle</IIM>, aprés que cet homme-là n'a pû se delivrer impunément de la crainte des Eclipses, que les Habitans de cette <UP></UP> Lune de Jupiter, dont nous parlions, en fussent quittes à meilleur marché. Nous ne leur ferons pas de quartier, ils subiront la Loy commune <UP></UP>, & donneront dans quelque autre erreur, mais comme je ne me pique pas de la pouvoir deviner, éclaircissez-moy, je vous prie, une autre difficulté qui m'occupe depuis quelques momens. Si la Terre est si petite à l'égard de Jupiter, Jupiter nous voit-il? Je crains que nous ne luy soyons inconnus.</P072> <P073>De bonne foy, je croy que cela est, répondis-je. Il faudroit qu'il vist la Terre quatre-vingt-dix fois plus petite que nous ne le voyons. C'est trop peu, il ne la voit point. Voicy seulement ce que nous pouvons croire de meilleur pour nous. Il y aura dans Jupiter des Astronomes, qui aprés avoir bien pris de la peine à composer des Lunettes excellentes, aprés avoir choisy les plus belles Nuits pour observer, auront enfin découvert dans les Cieux une petite Planete qu'ils n'avoyent jamais veüe. D'abord le <NCE>Journal des Sçavans</NCE> de ce Pays-là en parle; le Peuple de Jupiter, ou n'en entend point parler, ou n'en fait que rire. Les Philosophes dont cela détruit les opinions, forment le dessein de n'en rien croire, il n'y a que les Gens tres-raisonnables qui en veulent bien douter. On observe encore, on revoit la petite Planete, on s'asseure bien que ce n'est point une vision, on commence même à soupçonner qu'elle a un mouvement autour du Soleil; on trouve au bout de mille observations, que ce <RW>mouvement</RW> est d'une année; & enfin, grace à toutes les peines que se donnent les Sçavans, <NCP></NCP> on sçait dans Jupiter que nostre Terre est un Monde. Les Curieux vont la voir au bout d'une Lunette, & la veüe à peine peut-elle encore l'attraper.</P073>
chunks.target_manual: <P057>Let us go on with ours tho', says the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, and leave Ticho Brahe to defend his Superstition. Pray tell me, if the Earth be so little in comparison of Jupiter, whether his Inhabitants do discover us? Indeed, said I, I believe not; for if we appear to him ninety times less than he appears to us; judge you if there be any possibility: Yet this we may reasonably conjecture, that there are Astronomers in Jupiter, that after they have made the most curious Telescopes, and taken the clearest Night for their observations, they may have discover'd a little Planet in the Heavens, which they never saw before; if they publish their discovery, most People know not what they mean, or laugh at 'em for Fools; nay, the Philosophers themselves will not believe 'em, for fear of destroying their own opinions; yet some few may be a little curious; they continue their observations, discover the little Planet again, and are now assur'd it is no Vision; then they conclude it hath a motion round the Sun, which it compleats in a year, and at last, <NCP>(thanks to the Learned,)</NCP> they know in Jupiter our Earth is a World, every body runs to see it at the end of the Telescope, tho' 'tis so little, 'tis hardly discover'd.</P057>

Nous ne leur ferons pas de quartier, ils subiront la Loy commune, & donneront dans quelque autre erreur, mais comme je ne me pique pas de la pouvoir deviner, éclaircissez-moy, je vous prie, une autre difficulté qui m'occupe depuis quelques momens.
