explanations: The Marquise's original opening reflection in French—on the universal susceptibility to error and superstition, drawing a parallel between humans and hypothetical inhabitants of Jupiter's moon—is entirely omitted. The English translation replaces this extensive text with a new opening line that dismisses Tycho Brahe's 'Superstition.' This alters the Marquise's initial focus from a general philosophical point about shared fallibility to a specific, dismissive comment, changing the tone and immediate context of her subsequent question.

The translation changes 'Jupiter nous voit-il?' (Does Jupiter see us?) to 'whether his Inhabitants do discover us?', shifting agency from the personified planet to its inhabitants. More significantly, the Marquise's subsequent expression of concern, 'Je crains que nous ne luy soyons inconnus' (I fear that we are unknown to him), is entirely omitted from the corresponding part of the target text. This omission removes a key emotional nuance from her question, making her appear less reflective or apprehensive than in the original.

The philosopher's definitive statement in French, 'C'est trop peu, il ne la voit point' (That's too little, he [Jupiter] doesn't see it [Earth] at all), is transformed into a rhetorical question directed at the Marquise: 'judge you if there be any possibility:'. This manipulates the original by softening the philosopher's authoritative tone and shifting the responsibility of judgment to the Marquise, which is not Fontenelle's portrayal of the dynamic or the assertion's certainty.

The original French states that the Jovian 'Journal des Sçavans' *does* report the discovery ('en parle'). The English translation changes this to a conditional 'if they publish their discovery,'. This introduces an element of uncertainty about the dissemination of scientific knowledge on Jupiter that is not present in Fontenelle's text, subtly altering the depiction of their scientific community and its processes.

The French text describes those open to new astronomical discoveries as 'les Gens tres-raisonnables qui en veulent bien douter' (the very reasonable People who are willing to doubt [established views]). The translation changes this to 'yet some few may be a little curious;'. This significantly downplays the intellectual virtue Fontenelle attributes to these individuals, replacing 'very reasonable' and the active 'willingness to doubt' (a key Enlightenment trait) with the much weaker and more passive 'a little curious.' This subtly alters Fontenelle's commentary on the nature of scientific acceptance and the role of reason.

Fontenelle specifies that 'Les Curieux' (The Curious ones/those interested) go to see the newly discovered Earth through the telescope. The translation exaggerates this to 'every body runs to see it'. This changes the depiction of public engagement with the new scientific discovery from an interest primarily held by a select, curious group to a mass phenomenon, altering the implied social dynamics of knowledge dissemination on Jupiter as portrayed by Fontenelle.

chunks.source_manual: <P074>Si ce n'estoit, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, qu'il n'est point trop agreable de sçavoir qu'on ne nous peut découvrir de dedans Jupiter qu'avec des Lunettes d'approche, je me representerois avec plaisir ces Lunettes de Jupiter dressées vers nous, comme les nostres le sont vers luy, & cette curiosité mutuelle avec laquelle les Planetes s'entre-considerent & demandent l'une de l'autre, Quel monde est-ce-là? Quelles Gens l'habitent?</P074> <P075><IIM>Cela ne va pas si viste que vous pensez</IIM>, repliquay-je. Quand on verroit nostre Terre de dedans Jupiter, quand on l'y connoistroit, nostre Terre ce n'est pas nous; on n'a pas le moindre soupçon qu'elle puisse estre habitée. Si quelqu'un vient à se l'imaginer, Dieu sçait comme tout Jupiter se moque de luy. Peut-estre mesme sommes-nous cause qu'on y <UP>a fait le procés</UP> à des Philosophes qui ont voulu soûtenir que nous estions. Cependant je croirois plus volontiers que les Habitans de Jupiter sont assez occupez à faire des découvertes sur leur Planete, pour ne songer point du tout à nous. Elle est si grande, que s'ils navigent, asseurément <UP>leurs Cristophles Colombs ne sçauroient manquer d'employ</UP>. Il faut que les Peuples de ce Monde-là ne connoissent pas seulement de réputation la centiéme partie des autres Peuples, au lieu que dans Mercure, <NCP>qui est fort petit</NCP>, ils sont tous voisins les uns des autres, ils vivent familierement ensemble, & ne comptent que pour une promenade de faire le tour de leur Monde. Si on ne nous voit point dans Jupiter, vous jugez bien qu'on y voit encore moins Venus & Mercure, qui sont des Mondes, & plus petits, & plus éloignez de luy. En récompense ses Habitans voyent Mars, & leurs quatre Lunes, & Saturne <RW>avec les siennes</RW>. Voila assez de Planetes pour embarasser ceux d'entre eux qui sont Astronomes; la Nature a eu la bonté de leur cacher ce qui en reste dans l'Univers.</P075> <P076>Quoy, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, vous comptez cela pour une grace? Sans doute, répondis-je. Il y a dans tout ce grand <RW>Tourbillon</RW> seize Planetes. La Nature qui veut nous épargner la peine d'étudier tous leurs mouvemens, ne nous en montre que sept, n'est-ce pas là une assez grande faveur? Mais nous, qui n'en sentons pas le prix, nous faisons si bien que nous attrapons les neuf autres, qui avoient esté cachees; aussi en sommes-nous punis par les grands travaux que l'Astronomie demande presentement.</P076>
chunks.target_manual: <P058>It must be pleasant, says she, to see the Astronomers of both Planets, levelling their Tubes at one another, like two files of Musqueteers, and mutually asking, What World is that? What People inhabit it? Not so fast neither, I reply'd, for tho' they may from Jupiter discover our Earth, yet they may not know us; that is, they may not have the least suspicion it is inhabited; and should any one there chance to have such a fancy, he might be sufficiently ridicul'd, if not prosecuted for it; for my part, I believe they have work enough to make discoveries on their own Planet, not to trouble their Heads with ours; <UP>and had Sir Francis Drake and Columbus been in Jupiter, they might have had good employments</UP>; why, I warrant you, they have not yet discover'd the hundredth part of their Planet; when Mercury is so little, they are all <NCP>(as it were)</NCP> near Neighbours, and 'tis but taking a walk, to go round that Planet. But if we do not appear to 'em in Jupiter, they cannot certainly discover Venus and Mercury, which are much less than the Earth, and at a greater distance; but in lieu of it, they see Mars, their own four Moons, and Saturn, with his; this I think is work enough for their Astronomers; and Nature hath been so kind to conceal from 'em the rest of the Universe. Do you think it a favour then, says she? Yes, certainly, said I, for there are sixteen Planets in this great Vortex: Nature saves us the trouble of studying the Motions of 'em all, and shows us but seven, which I think is very obliging, tho' we know not how to value the kindness, for we have recover'd the other nine which were hid from us, and so render'd the Science of Astronomy much more difficult than Nature design'd it.</P058>

ces Lunettes de Jupiter dressées vers nous, comme les nostres le sont vers luy

the Astronomers of both Planets, levelling their Tubes at one another, like two files of Musqueteers
and had Sir Francis Drake and Columbus been in Jupiter, they might have had good employments
why, I warrant you, they have not yet discover'd the hundredth part of their Planet

explanations: The translation omits the Marquise's initial conditional clause ('Si ce n'estoit...qu'il n'est point trop agreable de sçavoir...'), which expresses a nuanced dissatisfaction or unease regarding Earth's insignificance requiring telescopes for discovery from Jupiter. By removing this qualifying phrase, the translation presents her subsequent imaginative thought ('je me representerois avec plaisir...') as stemming from an unreservedly 'pleasant' idea attributed to her directly ('It must be pleasant, says she,'), thus simplifying her complex emotion and altering the initial tone of her reflection from conditional and slightly melancholic to simply pleasant.

The original French describes the Marquise imagining 'ces Lunettes de Jupiter dressées vers nous' (Jupiter's telescopes aimed at us), focusing on the instruments and the act of mutual observation. The translation shifts the focus from the telescopes to 'the Astronomers...levelling their Tubes' and, significantly, introduces the simile 'like two files of Musqueteers.' This simile is entirely absent from the original and injects a militaristic or confrontational image, changing the tone from one of scientific curiosity and wonder to something more akin to a standoff, thereby altering the reader's perception of the imagined interplanetary interaction.

The original French uses 'leurs Cristophles Colombs' (their Christopher Columbuses) in the plural, signifying a generic type of great explorer native to Jupiter. The translation changes this by adding the specific English figure 'Sir Francis Drake' alongside a singular 'Columbus.' This anglicization localizes the reference for the English audience, diminishing the universal, hypothetical nature of Fontenelle's statement. It also shifts the implication from Jupiter having its own great explorers to Earth's explorers potentially finding work there, subtly altering the focus.

The original text speculates that 'les Peuples de ce Monde-là ne connoissent pas...la centiéme partie des autres Peuples' (the Peoples of that World do not know...the hundredth part of the other Peoples [on their own vast planet]). The translation renders this as 'they have not yet discover'd the hundredth part of their Planet.' This alters the meaning by shifting the focus from a lack of inter-societal awareness or knowledge between different populations on Jupiter to a purely geographical or territorial ignorance (discovery of the planet itself). This subtly changes the imagined nature of Jupiter's internal exploration and societal development.

The French original uses the strong term 'punis' ('aussi en sommes-nous punis' - also we are punished for it), implying a form of retribution or negative consequence for humanity's over-eager pursuit of hidden knowledge. The translation softens this significantly to 'and so render'd the Science of Astronomy much more difficult than Nature design'd it.' This reframing replaces the notion of 'punishment' with the idea of making a science 'more difficult' and introduces 'Nature's design,' thereby lessening the moral or critical weight of the original statement and shifting the tone away from a direct consequence of hubris. This change could reflect a desire to mitigate any perceived challenge to the pursuit of science in the English context.

The original French text employs a rhetorical question, 'n'est-ce pas là une assez grande faveur?' (is that not a great enough favor?), which carries an assertive tone and expects agreement on the considerable nature of Nature's 'favor' in showing only seven planets. The translation changes this to a more subdued declarative statement, 'which I think is very obliging.' This alteration weakens the force of the philosopher's assertion, making it sound more like a polite personal opinion ('I think,' 'obliging') rather than a strong, almost self-evident point about the magnitude of Nature's kindness, thereby reducing the original's emphatic tone.

chunks.source_manual: <P077>Je voy, reprit-elle, par ce nombre de seize Planetes qu'il faut que Saturne ait cinq Lunes. Il les a aussi, repliquay-je, & de ces cinq Lunes, il y en a deux bien fraischement découvertes; mais il ya a quelque chose qui est encore bien plus remarquable. Comme son année est de trente des nostres, & que par consequent il a <IIM>des Pays</IIM>, où une seule nuit dure des quinze ans entiers, devinez ce que la Nature a inventé pour éclaires des nuits si affreuses. Elle ne s'est pas contentée de donner cinq Lunes à Saturne, elle a mis autour de luy un grand Cercle, ou un grand Anneau qui l'environne entierement, & qui estant assez élevé pour estre hors de l'ombre du Corps de cette Planete, refléchit perpetuellement la lumiere du Soleil <RW>dans les lieux qui ne le voyent point</RW>.</P077>
chunks.target_manual: <P059>If there are sixteen Planets, says she, Saturn must have five Moons. 'Tis very true, said I, and two of these five, are but lately discover'd; but there is somewhat that is more remarkable, since his Year is thirty of ours, there are consequently in him some Countreys, where their Night is fifteen years long; and what can you imagine Nature hath invented to give light, during so dreadful a Night? Why, she hath not only given Saturn five Moons, but she hath encompass'd him round with a great Circle or Ring, the which being plac'd beyond the reach of the shadow which the Body of that Planet casts, reflects the light of the Sun continually on those places where they cannot see the Sun at all.</P059>
source_segments: Elle ne s'est pas contentée de donner cinq Lunes à Saturne
target_segments: Why, she hath not only given Saturn five Moons
explanations: The French phrase 'Elle ne s'est pas contentée de donner cinq Lunes à Saturne' ('She was not content to give five Moons to Saturn') is a straightforward declarative statement. The English translation prefaces the corresponding clause with the interjection 'Why,'. This addition, entirely absent from the original French, subtly alters the tone of the philosopher's speech. It injects an element of emphatic or exclamatory conversational style, potentially making the philosopher's delivery seem more animated or theatrical than the more measured and elegant tone of the original French text, thereby shifting the reader's perception of his character's speaking style.

chunks.source_manual: <P078>En verité, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, <IIM>de l'air d'une personne qui rentroit en elle-mesme avec étonnement</IIM>, tout cela est d'un grand ordre; il paroist bien que la Nature a eu en veüe les besoins de quelques Estres vivans, & que la distribution des Lunes n'a pas esté faite au hazard. Il n'en est tombé en partage qu'aux Planetes éloignées du Soleil, à la Terre, à Jupiter, à Saturne, car ce n'estoit pas la peine d'en donner à Venus & à Mercure, qui ne reçoivent que trop de lumiere, dont les nuits sont fort courtes, & qui les comptent apparemment pour de plus grands bienfaits de la Nature que leurs jours mesmes. Mais attendez, il me semble que Mars, qui est encore plus éloigné du Soleil que la Terre, n'a <IIM>point de Lune</IIM>. On ne peut pas vous le dissimuler, répondis-je, il n'en a point, & il faut qu'il ait pour ses nuits des ressources que nous ne sçavons pas. Vous avez veu des <SC>Phosphores</SC>, de ces matieres liquides ou seches, qui en recevant la lumiere du Soleil, s'en imbibent, & s'en penetrent, & ensuite jettent un assez grand éclat dans l'obscurité. <SC>Peut-estre Mars a-t-il</SC> de grands Rochers fort élevéz, qui sont des <SC>Phosphores</SC> naturels, & qui prennent pendant le jour une provision de lumiere qu'ils rendent pendant la nuit. Vous ne sçauriez nier que ce ne fust un Spectacle assez agreable, de voir tous ces Rochers s'alumer de toutes parts dés que le Soleil seroit couché, & faire sans aucun art des illuminations magnifiques. Vous sçavez encore qu'il y a en Amerique des Oyseaux qui sont si lumineux dans les tenebres, qu'on s'en peut servir pour lire. Que sçavons-nous si Mars n'a point un grand nombre de ces Oyseaux, qui dés que la nuit est venuë, se dispersent de tous costéz, & vont répandre un nouveau jour?</P078>
chunks.target_manual: <P060>I protest, says the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, this is very surprizing, and yet all is contriv'd in such great order, that it is impossible not to think but Nature took time to consider the necessities of all animate Beings, and that the disposing of these Moons was not a work of Chance, for they are only divided among those Planets which are farthest distant from the Sun, the Earth, Jupiter, Saturn; indeed it was not worth while to give any to Mercury or Venus, they have too much light already; and they account their nights (as short as they are) a greater blessing than their day. But pray, why has not Mars a Moon too? It seems he has none, tho' he is much further than the Earth from the Sun. It is very true, said I; no doubt but he hath other helps, tho' we do not know 'em: You have seen the Phosphorus, both liquid and dry, how it receives and imbibes the rays of the Sun, and what a great light it will cast in a dark Place: Perhaps Mars hath many great high Rocks, which are so many natural Phosphorus's, which in the day take in a certain provision of light, and return it again at night. What think you, Madam, is it not very pleasant when the Sun is down to see those lighted Rocks, like so many Illuminations at a Birth day night? Besides, there is a kind of Bird in America, that yields such a light, you may read by it in the darkest night; and who knows but Mars may have great flocks of these Birds, that as soon as it is night, disperse themselves into all parts, and spread from their wings another day.</P060>
source_segments: quelques Estres vivans
il paroist bien que la Nature a eu en veüe
qui les comptent apparemment pour de plus grands bienfaits de la Nature que leurs jours mesmes.
il faut qu'il ait
faire sans aucun art des illuminations magnifiques.
target_segments: all animate Beings
it is impossible not to think but Nature took time to consider
and they account their nights (as short as they are) a greater blessing than their day.
no doubt but he hath
like so many Illuminations at a Birth day night?
explanations: The French 'quelques Estres vivans' (some living Beings) is broadened to 'all animate Beings' in the English translation. This changes Fontenelle's more cautious and limited observation into a universal, absolute statement about Nature's providence, potentially to resonate with a readership accustomed to stronger assertions of a designed universe, thereby manipulating the reader's perception of the scope and certainty of the claim.

The translation significantly intensifies the original statement. 'il paroist bien que' (it is quite apparent that/it appears well that) becomes 'it is impossible not to think but,' a much stronger and more convoluted assertion of certainty. Additionally, 'a eu en veüe' (had in view/envisaged) is anthropomorphized to 'took time to consider,' imbuing Nature with more deliberate, human-like cognition. This shift manipulates the reader by presenting the idea of Nature's design with a heightened, almost dogmatic, sense of deliberation and inevitability.

The French 'apparemment' (apparently, seemingly), which qualifies the certainty of the statement about the inhabitants of Venus and Mercury, is omitted in the English translation of the clause. This omission results in presenting a speculative idea as a more definite fact, subtly manipulating the reader by increasing the perceived authority and factual basis of the speaker's claim regarding the preferences of these extraterrestrial beings.

The French 'il faut qu'il ait' (he must have / it is necessary that he has), found in 'il faut qu'il ait pour ses nuits des ressources', implies a logical necessity or strong supposition. The English 'no doubt but he hath', in 'no doubt but he hath other helps', translates this with a higher degree of certainty ('no doubt'). This shift manipulates the reader by presenting the philosopher's speculation with more conviction than the original text conveys, thereby subtly altering the epistemic stance of the assertion.

The French 'sans aucun art' (without any art/artifice) emphasizes the purely natural and uncrafted nature of the 'illuminations magnifiques.' The English translation omits this emphasis on naturalness and instead adds the culturally specific comparison 'like so many Illuminations at a Birth day night?'. This addition domesticates the alien spectacle by likening it to a familiar human celebration (resonant in 17th-century England), thereby shifting the reader's perception from a sublime natural wonder to a more artificial, festive event, altering the original imagery and connotations.

chunks.source_manual: <P079>Je ne me contente, reprit-elle, ny de vos Rochers, ni de vos Oyseaux. Cela ne laisseroit pas d'estre joly, mais puis que la Nature a donné tant de Lunes à Saturne & à Jupiter, c'est une marque qu'il faut des Lunes. J'eusse esté bien-aise que tous les Mondes éloignez du Soleil en eussent eu, si Mars ne nous fust point venu faire une exception desagreable. Ah! vrayment, repliquay-je, si <LS><IIM>vous vous mêliez de Philosophie plus que vous ne faites</IIM></LS>, il faudroit bien que vous vous accoûtumassiez à voir des exceptions dans les meilleurs Sistêmes. Il y a toûjours quelque chose qui y convient le plus juste du monde, & puis quelque chose aussi qu'on y fait convenir comme on peut, ou qu'on laisse-là, si on desespere d'en pouvoir venir à bout. Usons-en de mesme pour Mars, puis qu'il ne nous est point favorable, & ne parlons point de luy. Nous serions bien étonnez, si nous estions dans Saturne, de voir sur nos testes pendant la nuit ce grand Anneau qui iroit en forme de demy Cercle d'un bout à l'autre de l'Horison, & qui nous renvoyant la lumiere du Soleil feroit l'effet d'une Lune continuë. Et ne mettrons-nous point d'Habitans dans ce grand Anneau, interrompit-elle en riant? Quoy que je sois d'humeur, répondis-je, à en envoyer par tout assez hardiment, je vous avoüe que je n'oserois en mettre là, cet Anneau me paroist une habitation trop irreguliere. Pour les cinq petites Lunes, on ne peut pas se dispenser de les peupler. Si cependant l'Anneau n'estoit, comme quelques-uns le soupçonnent, qu'un Cercle de Lunes qui se suivissent de fort prés, & eussent un mouvement égal, & que les cinq petites Lunes fussent trois échapées de ce grand Cercle, que de Mondes dans le Tourbillon de Saturne! Quoy qu'il en soit, avec le secours même de l'Anneau, les Gens de Saturne sont assez miserables. Il leur donne de la lumiere, mais quelle lumiere, dans l'éloignement où il est du Soleil! Le Soleil même n'est pour eux qu'une petite Etoile blanche & pâle, qui n'a qu'un éclat & une chaleur bien foible, & si vous les mettiez dans nos Pays les plus froids, dans la Groënlande, ou dans la Laponie, vous les verriez suër à grosses gouttes & expirer de chaud.</P079>
chunks.target_manual: <P061>I am not at all contented, says she, with your Rocks, or your Birds; 'tis a pretty fancy indeed, but 'tis a sign that there should be Moons in Mars, since Nature hath given so many to Saturn, and Jupiter; and if all the other Worlds that are distant from the Sun, have Moons, why should Mars only be excepted? Ah, Madam, said I, when you are a little more dip'd in Philosophy, you will find exceptions in the very best Systemes; there are always some things that agree extream well, but then there are others that do not accord at all; those you must leave as you found 'em, if ever you intend to make an end: We will do so by Mars, if you please, and say no more of him; but return to Saturn. What do you think of his great Ring, in the form of a semy Circle, that reaches from one end of the Horizon to the other, which reflecting the light of the Sun, performs the office of a continual Moon. And must we not inhabit this Ring too, says she? I confess, said I, in the humour I am in, I could almost send Colonies every where; and yet I can't well plant any there, it seems so irregular an habitation; but for the five little Moons, they cannot chuse but be inhabited; tho' some think this Ring is a Circle of Moons, which follow close to one another, and have one equal Motion; and that the five little Moons fell out of this Circle; how many Worlds are there then in the <UP>Vortex of Saturn</UP>? But let it be how it will, the People in Saturn live very miserably: 'Tis true, this Ring gives light to 'em, but it must be a very poor one, when the Sun seems to 'em but a little pale Star, whose light and heat cannot but be very weak at so great a distance; they say Greenland is a perfect Bagnio in comparison of that Planet, and that they would expire with heat in our coldest Countreys.</P061>
source_segments: c'est une marque qu'il faut des Lunes.
ou qu'on laisse-là, si on desespere d'en pouvoir venir à bout.
puis qu'il ne nous est point favorable
interrompit-elle en riant?
et que les cinq petites Lunes fussent trois échapées de ce grand Cercle
si vous les mettiez dans nos Pays les plus froids, dans la Groënlande, ou dans la Laponie, vous les verriez suër à grosses gouttes & expirer de chaud.
target_segments: 'tis a sign that there should be Moons in Mars
those you must leave as you found 'em, if ever you intend to make an end:
if you please
says she?
and that the five little Moons fell out of this Circle
they say Greenland is a perfect Bagnio in comparison of that Planet, and that they would expire with heat in our coldest Countreys.
explanations: The Marquise's original French statement "c'est une marque qu'il faut des Lunes" expresses a general deduction that moons are necessary or indicated by nature, based on Saturn and Jupiter. The translation alters this by making her deduction specific to Mars ("there should be Moons in Mars"), thereby narrowing the scope of her reasoning and changing her general observation into a direct assertion about a particular planet.

The philosopher's original justification for abandoning problematic parts of a system is the despair of resolving them ("si on desespere d'en pouvoir venir à bout"). The translation shifts this rationale to one of expediency or project completion ("if ever you intend to make an end"), subtly altering the portrayal of intellectual compromise from being about insurmountable difficulty to pragmatic necessity.

The philosopher in the original text gives a specific reason for not discussing Mars ("puis qu'il ne nous est point favorable," meaning 'since it is not favorable to our system/argument'). The translation omits this intellectual justification and replaces it with a simple polite deference to the Marquise ("if you please"), thereby changing the philosopher's stated motivation and weakening the portrayal of his systematic thinking.

The original French describes the Marquise interrupting "en riant" (laughing), which imparts a light-hearted, playful, or perhaps even self-awarely skeptical tone to her question about inhabiting Saturn's ring. The translation's omission of "en riant" removes this crucial tonal information, potentially making her interruption seem more abrupt, serious, or challenging than intended, thus subtly altering the reader's perception of her character and the conversational dynamic.

The original French text includes the specific number "trois" (three) in relation to the speculative origin of Saturn's five moons from its ring ("fussent trois échapées" – were three escaped [entities/groups, or escaped in three instances]). While the exact meaning of "trois" here is open to interpretation, its presence suggests a specific numerical or categorical detail in Fontenelle's hypothesis. The translation omits this number entirely, generalizing the event to "the five little Moons fell out of this Circle." This omission removes a specific element of the original speculation, simplifying it and altering the reader's understanding of the nuance in Fontenelle's imaginative scientific discourse.

The original French describes a hypothetical scenario: Saturnians, if placed in Earth's coldest regions (Greenland or Lapland), would experience extreme heat subjectively ("vous les verriez suër... & expirer de chaud"). The translation significantly alters this by changing the direct hypothetical statement into reported speech ("they say"), transforming the subjective experience into an objective-sounding comparison by stating "Greenland is a perfect Bagnio in comparison of that Planet" (a more sensationalized image), and focusing only on Greenland for this vivid comparison. This manipulation shifts the statement from a reasoned thought experiment about adaptation to a piece of reported, extreme comparison, altering the tone and authority of the assertion.

chunks.source_manual: <P080>Vous me donnez une idée de Saturne qui me gele, dit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, au lieu que tantost vous m'échauffiez en me parlant de Mercure. Il faut bien, repliquay-je, que les deux Mondes qui sont aux extremitez de ce grand Tourbillon, soient opposées en toutes choses.</P080> <P081>Ainsi, reprit-elle, on est bien sage dans Saturne, car vous m'avez dit que tout le monde estoit fou dans Mercure. Si on n'est pas bien sage dans Saturne, repris- je, du moins, selon toutes les apparences, on y est bien flegmatique. Ce sont Gens qui ne sçavent ce que c'est que de rire, qui prennent toûjours un jour pour répondre à la moindre question qu'on leur fait, & qui eussent trouvé Caton d'Utique <IIM>trop badin & trop folâtre</IIM>. <NCE></NCE>.</P081>
chunks.target_manual: <P062>You give me, says she, such an Idea of Saturn, that makes me shake with cold, and that of Mercury, puts me into a feaver. It cannot be otherwise, I reply'd, for the two Worlds, which are the extremities of this great Vortex, must be opposite in all things. They must then, says she, be very wise in Saturn, for you told me they were all Fools in Mercury. If they are not wise, said I, yet they have all the appearances of being very Flegmatick: They are People that know not what 'tis to laugh, they take a days time to answer the least question you can ask 'em; and are so very grave, that were Cato living among 'em, they would think him <NCE>a merry Andrew</NCE>.</P062>
source_segments: tantost vous m'échauffiez en me parlant de Mercure
& qui eussent trouvé Caton d'Utique trop badin & trop folâtre.
target_segments: and that of Mercury, puts me into a feaver
and are so very grave, that were Cato living among 'em, they would think him a merry Andrew.
explanations: The French "vous m'échauffiez" translates to "you were warming me" or "you were exciting me." The English translation "puts me into a feaver" intensifies this sensation significantly. While "fever" can metaphorically denote intense excitement, its primary connotation is often pathological, suggesting illness or extreme, uncontrolled agitation. The original term "échauffer" is more general and lacks this inherent negative or medical implication. This shift in translation subtly manipulates the reader's perception by framing the effect of discussing Mercury as more extreme and potentially unhealthy than the original text suggests, pushing the Marquise's reaction closer to the "madness" later attributed to Mercurians.

The original French states that the extremely serious inhabitants of Saturn would have found Cato of Utica (a figure known for his stoicism) "trop badin & trop folâtre" (too playful/joking and too frolicsome/light-hearted). This highlights the Saturnians' exceptional gravity. The English translation changes this to "they would think him a merry Andrew." A "merry Andrew" is a clown or buffoon. This alteration is a clear manipulation because it: 1. Replaces relatively mild French terms describing a slight lack of seriousness with a strong, derogatory English idiom implying foolishness. 2. Changes the perceived judgment of Cato from merely "not serious enough" by Saturnian standards to being an outright fool, thus exaggerating the Saturnians' character or making their judgment seem cruder. 3. Introduces a culturally specific English term ("merry Andrew") that lowers the register and alters the tone of the comparison from a refined, philosophical observation to a more comical and less nuanced caricature, thereby shifting the reader's understanding of both the Saturnians and the hypothetical assessment of Cato.

chunks.source_manual: <P082>Il me vient une pensée, dit-elle. Tous les Habitans de Mercure sont vifs, tous ceux de Saturne sont lens. Parmy nous les uns sont vifs, les autres lents; cela ne viendroit-il point de ce que nostre Terre étant justement au milieu des autres Mondes, nous participons des extremitez? Il n'y a point pour les hommes de Caractere fixe & déterminé; les uns sont faits comme les Habitans de Mercure, les autres comme ceux de Saturne, & nous sommes un mélange de toutes les especes qui se trouvent dans les autres Planetes. J'aime assez cette idée, repris- je, nous formons un assemblage si bizarre, qu'on pourroit croire que nous serions ramassez de plusieurs Mondes différens. A ce compte, il est assez commode d'estre icy, on y voit tous les autres Mondes en abregé.</P082>
chunks.target_manual: <P063>It is odd to consider, says she, that the Inhabitants of Mercury are all life, and the Inhabitants of Saturn quite contrary; but among us, some are brisk, and some are dull; it is, I suppose, because our Earth is plac'd in the middle of the other Worlds, and so we participate of both extreams, there is no fix'd or determin'd Character; some are made like the Inhabitants of Mercury, some like those of Saturn; we are a mixture of the several kinds that are found in the rest of the Planets. Why, said I, do you not approve of the Idea? Methinks it is pleasant to be compos'd of such a fantastical Assembly, that one would think we were collected out of different Worlds; we need not travel, when we see the other Worlds in Epitome at home.</P063>
source_segments: Il me vient une pensée, dit-elle.
J'aime assez cette idée, repris- je,
il est assez commode d'estre icy,
target_segments: It is odd to consider, says she,
Why, said I, do you not approve of the Idea?
we need not travel,
explanations: The original French 'Il me vient une pensée, dit-elle.' (A thought comes to me / I have a thought, she said.) is a neutral statement about a thought occurring to the Marquise. The translation 'It is odd to consider, says she,' introduces the subjective adjective 'odd', which is not present in the original. This addition subtly alters the Marquise's tone, making her seem to pre-judge her own thought or the topic as peculiar, potentially diminishing her intellectual assertiveness, whereas the original portrays a simple, un-self-conscious emergence of an idea.

The philosopher's original French response 'J'aime assez cette idée, repris- je,' (I quite like this idea, I replied,) expresses direct agreement and support for the Marquise's preceding thought. The translation 'Why, said I, do you not approve of the Idea?' completely changes this affirmative statement into a question directed at the Marquise, seemingly challenging her or probing her own approval of her idea. This manipulates the reader's understanding of the philosopher's character, making him appear more interrogative or confrontational rather than immediately supportive, and alters the collaborative dynamic of the dialogue.

The original French 'il est assez commode d'estre icy,' (it is quite convenient/advantageous to be here,) directly states a positive quality of their current situation. The translation 'we need not travel,' replaces this statement of inherent convenience with a specific practical consequence (avoiding the effort of travel). This shifts the focus from the intrinsic advantage of their location ('being here is convenient') to a utilitarian outcome ('we don't have to do something'), thereby omitting the direct expression of convenience and subtly altering the nuance of the philosopher's reflection.

chunks.source_manual: <P083>Du moins, reprit la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, une commodité fort réelle qu'a nostre Monde par sa situation, c'est qu'il n'est ny si chaud que celuy de Mercure ou de Venus, ny si froid que celuy de Jupiter ou de Saturne. De plus, nous sommes justement dans un endroit de la Terre où nous ne sentons l'excés ny du chaud ni du froid. En verité si un certain Philosophe rendoit grace à la Nature d'estre Homme, & non pas Beste, Grec, & non pas Barbare, moy je veux luy rendre grace d'estre sur la Planete la plus tempérée de l'Univers, & dans un des lieux les plus temperez de cette Planete. Si vous m'en croyez, Madame, répondis-je, vous luy rendrez grace d'estre jeune & non pas vieille; jeune & belle, & non pas jeune & laide; jeune & belle Françoise, & non pas jeune & <UP></UP> belle Italienne. Voila bien d'autres sujets de reconnoissance que ceux que vous tirez de la situation de vostre Tourbillon, ou de la temperature de vostre Pays.</P083>
chunks.target_manual: <P064>I am sure, says the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, we have one great convenience in the situation of our World; it is not so hot as Mercury or Venus, nor so cold as Jupiter or Saturn; and our Country is so justly plac'd, that we have no excess either of Heat or Cold. I have heard of a Philosopher, who gave thanks to Nature that he was born a Man, and not a Beast, a Greek, and not a Barbarian; and for my part, I render thanks that I am seated in the most temperate Planet of the Universe, and in one of the most temperate Regions of that Planet. You have more reason, said I, to give thanks that you are Young, and not Old; that you are Young and Handsome, and not Young and Ugly; that you are Young, Handsome, and an English Woman, and not Young, Handsome, <UP>and a Spaniard</UP>, or an Italian; these are other guess Subjects for your thanks, than the Situation of your Vortex, or the Temperature of your Countrey.</P064>
source_segments: la Marquise
un endroit de la Terre
jeune & belle Françoise
non pas jeune & belle Italienne
target_segments: the Countess
our Country
Young, Handsome, and an English Woman
not Young, Handsome, and a Spaniard, or an Italian
explanations: The French title "Marquise" (whose direct English equivalent is "Marchioness") is translated as "the Countess." This changes the character's specific noble rank and, in conjunction with other anglicizing alterations, subtly diminishes her distinctly French aristocratic identity, making her more akin to an English noblewoman for the target audience. This shifts the reader's perception by domesticating a key character.

The original French "un endroit de la Terre" (a place on Earth), referring to a specific favorable geographical location, is translated as "our Country." This alters the meaning by injecting a nationalistic sentiment not present in Fontenelle's text. It manipulates the reader by framing the Marquise's (now Countess's) appreciation of her environment as patriotic pride, likely intended to resonate with an English audience's feelings about England.

The philosopher's remark identifies the ideal of being a "jeune & belle Françoise" (young and beautiful Frenchwoman). The translation explicitly changes this to "Young, Handsome, and an English Woman." This is a direct substitution of nationality, manipulating the text to flatter the English readership by centering English identity as the ideal, thereby domesticating the compliment and appealing to national pride.

In the original, the Frenchwoman is contrasted with an "Italienne" (Italian woman). The translation, having already changed "Frenchwoman" to "English Woman," alters the contrasting group to "a Spaniard, or an Italian." The addition of "Spaniard" is significant; Spain was a major Catholic power and often a political and religious antagonist to Protestant England in the late 17th century. This addition manipulates the reader by introducing a nationality with strong negative connotations for the English audience of the time, thereby heightening the implied preference for the "English Woman" by contrasting her with figures from nations viewed as rivals or culturally "other".

chunks.source_manual: <P084>Mon Dieu! repliqua-t-elle, laissez-moy avoir de la reconnaissance sur tout, jusque sur le Tourbillon où je suis placée. La mesure de bonheur qui nous a esté donnée, est assez petite; il n'en faut rien perdre, & il est bon d'avoir pour les choses les plus communes, & les moins considerables, un goust qui les mette à profit. Si on ne vouloit que des plaisirs vifs, on en auroit peu, on les attendroit long-temps, & on les payeroit bien. Vous me promettez donc, repliquay-je, que si on vous proposoit de ces plaisirs vifs, vous vous souviendriez des Tourbillons & de moy, & que vous vous borneriez à nous? Ouy, répondit-elle, mais faites que la Philosophie me fournisse toûjours des plaisirs nouveaux. Du moins pour demain, répondis-je, j'espere qu'ils ne vous manqueront pas. J'ai des Etoiles Fixes qui passent tout ce que vous avez veu jusqu'icy.</P084>
chunks.target_manual: <P065>Pray Sir, says she, let me give thanks for all things, to the very Vortex in which I am planted: Our proportion of Happiness is so very small, that we should lose none, but improve continually what we have, and be grateful for every thing, tho' never so common or inconsiderable. If nothing but exquisite pleasure will serve us, we must wait a long time, and be sure to pay too dear for it at last. I wish, said I, that Philosophy was the pleasure you propose, that when you think of Vortex's, you would not forget an humble Servant of your Ladyships. I esteem it a pleasure, says she, while it diverts innocently, but no longer. I will engage for it till to morrow, I reply'd, for the fix'd Stars are beyond what you have yet seen.</P065>
source_segments: Mon Dieu!
Vous me promettez donc, repliquay-je, que si on vous proposoit de ces plaisirs vifs, vous vous souviendriez des Tourbillons & de moy, & que vous vous borneriez à nous?
Ouy, répondit-elle, mais faites que la Philosophie me fournisse toûjours des plaisirs nouveaux.
un goust qui les mette à profit
j'espere qu'ils ne vous manqueront pas
target_segments: Pray Sir
I wish, said I, that Philosophy was the pleasure you propose, that when you think of Vortex's, you would not forget an humble Servant of your Ladyships.
I esteem it a pleasure, says she, while it diverts innocently, but no longer.
improve continually what we have
I will engage for it
explanations: The French "Mon Dieu!" is a common exclamation of surprise or emphasis. The translation to "Pray Sir" changes it into a direct, polite address to the philosopher, altering the tone from a general exclamation to a specific entreaty. This subtly manipulates the reader's perception of the Marquise's character, making her expression more formal and less spontaneous, possibly to align with perceived English decorum.

The philosopher's original playful question, asking the Marquise if she would remember him and his teachings (and limit herself to them) if offered "plaisirs vifs" (intense pleasures), is entirely replaced. The translation substitutes a formal wish that philosophy be her preferred pleasure and transforms the personal "moy" (me) into the deferential "an humble Servant of your Ladyships." This manipulation significantly alters the philosopher's tone from familiar and challenging to formal and subservient, changing the dynamic of their relationship and removing the original text's subtle exploration of competing pleasures.

The Marquise's original affirmative response ("Ouy" - Yes) and her subsequent demand for philosophy to continuously provide "plaisirs nouveaux" (new pleasures) are completely altered. The translation omits her affirmation and replaces her demand with a conditional acceptance: she esteems philosophy a pleasure only "while it diverts innocently, but no longer." The introduction of the qualifier "innocently" is a significant addition, imposing a moral condition on her engagement with philosophy that is absent in the source. This manipulation reframes her intellectual curiosity as acceptable only within narrower, morally constrained bounds, potentially reflecting societal anxieties of the target culture regarding women's engagement with new scientific ideas.

The French phrase "un goust qui les mette à profit" describes having a taste or appreciation that allows one to benefit from or make good use of common things. The translation to "improve continually what we have" shifts the emphasis from appreciation and skillful utilization to an active, ongoing process of betterment. This subtly alters the Marquise's philosophical stance, potentially reflecting a different cultural emphasis on continuous improvement over contentment with and appreciation of the existing.

The philosopher's original French statement "j'espere qu'ils ne vous manqueront pas" (I hope that they [new pleasures] will not be lacking for you / will not fail you) expresses a modest hope. The English translation "I will engage for it" (meaning I will guarantee it or take responsibility for providing it) conveys a much stronger commitment or assurance. This shift in wording subtly manipulates the philosopher's tone, making him sound more confident or assertive than in the original.

chunks.source_manual: <P085>CINQUIEME SOIR.</P085>
chunks.target_manual: <P066>The Fifth Evening.</P066>

chunks.source_manual: <P086><UP></UP>. La <IIM>Marquise</IIM> sentit une vraye impatience de sçavoir ce que les Etoiles Fixes deviendroient. Seront-elles habitées comme les Planetes, me dit-elle? Ne le seront-elles pas? Enfin qu'en ferons-nous? Vous le devineriez peut-estre, si vous en aviez bien envie, répondis-je. Les Etoiles Fixes ne sçauroient estre moins éloignées de la Terre que de quelques cinquante millions de lieuës, & si vous fâchiez un Astronome, il les mettroit encore plus loin. La distance du Soleil à la Planete la plus éloignée, n'est rien par rapport à la distance du Soleil ou de la Terre aux Etoiles Fixes, & on ne prend pas la peine de la compter. Leur lumiere, comme vous voyez, est assez vive & assez éclatante. Si elles la recevoient du Soleil, il faudroit qu'elles la receussent déja bien foible aprés un trajet de <IIM>cinquante millions de lieuës</IIM> <UP></UP>; il faudroit que par une reflexion qui l'affoibliroit encore beaucoup, elles nous la renvoyassent à cette mesme distance. Il seroit impossible qu'une lumiere qui auroit essuyé une reflexion, & fait deux fois <IIM>cinquante millions de lieuës</IIM>, eust cette force et cette vivacité qu'a celle des Etoiles Fixes. Les voila donc lumineuses par elles-mêmes, & toutes, en un mot, autant de Soleils.</P086>
chunks.target_manual: <P067>THE <IIM>Countess</IIM> was very impatient to know what would become of the fix'd Stars; are they inhabited, says she, as the Planets are, or are they not inhabited? What shall we do with 'em? You may soon guess, said I; the fix'd Stars cannot be less distant from the Earth than fifty millions of leagues; nay, if you anger an Astronomer, he will set 'em further. The distance from the Sun to the farthest Planet, is nothing in comparison of the distance from the Sun, or from the Earth, to the fix'd Stars, it is almost beyond Arithmetick. You see their light is bright and shining, and did they receive it from the Sun, it must needs be very weak after a passage of <NCE>fifty millions of leagues</NCE>; then judge how much it is wasted by reflection; for it comes back again as far to us; so that forwards and backwards, here are <NCE>an hundred millions of leagues</NCE> for it to pass; and it is impossible it should be so clear and strong as the light of a fix'd Star, which cannot but proceed from it self; so that in a word, all the fix'd Stars are so many Suns.</P067>

& on ne prend pas la peine de la compter.
il faudroit que par une reflexion qui l'affoibliroit encore beaucoup, elles nous la renvoyassent à cette mesme distance.
target_segments: You may soon guess
it is almost beyond Arithmetick.
then judge how much it is wasted by reflection; for it comes back again as far to us;
explanations: The original French "Vous le devineriez peut-estre, si vous en aviez bien envie" (You would perhaps guess it, if you truly desired it/put your mind to it) conveys a conditional possibility hinging on the Marquise's active intellectual curiosity and effort ("bien envie") along with an element of uncertainty ("peut-estre"). The translation "You may soon guess" omits "perhaps" and replaces the condition of strong desire/effort with "soon," suggesting the answer is simple and easily attainable. This subtly alters the dynamic by downplaying the Marquise's intellectual agency and the role of her personal engagement, making the philosopher's tone more direct and the process of discovery seem less dependent on the Marquise's keen interest or application.

The original French "& on ne prend pas la peine de la compter" means "and one doesn't (even) bother to count/include it," referring to the Sun-to-outermost-planet distance being negligible *in comparison* to the vast Earth-to-stars distance. The translation "it is almost beyond Arithmetick." fundamentally changes the meaning. Instead of highlighting the relative insignificance of one distance in a comparative calculation, it suggests that the stellar distance itself is so immense as to be almost incalculable or beyond the scope of mathematics. This introduces a sense of overwhelming magnitude not explicitly stated in the original phrase, which is more focused on the practicalities of astronomical comparison.

The French "il faudroit que... elles nous la renvoyassent" describes a necessary consequence within a hypothesis: "(if stars reflected sunlight), it would be necessary that... they would send it back to us," with the reflection further weakening ("affoibliroit") the light. The translation shifts from this descriptive deduction to an imperative, "then judge how much it is wasted by reflection". This alters the philosopher's mode of discourse from guiding a shared logical inference to instructing the Marquise to make an evaluative judgment. The term "wasted" is also an interpretation, introducing a notion of loss or inefficiency not explicit in the original "affoibliroit" (would weaken), thereby subtly changing the tone and the character of the scientific explanation.

chunks.source_manual: <P087>Ne me trompay-je point, s'écria la <IIM>Marquise</IIM>, ou si je vois où vous me voulez mener? M'allez-vous dire: Les Etoiles Fixes sont autant de Soleils, nostre Soleil est le centre d'un Tourbillon qui tourne autour de luy, pourquoy chaque Etoile Fixe ne sera-t-elle pas aussi le centre d'un Tourbillon qui aura un mouvement autour d'elle? Nostre Soleil a des Planetes qu'il éclaire, pourquoy chaque Etoile Fixe n'en aura-t-elle pas aussi qu'elle éclairera? Je n'ay à vous répondre, luy dis-je, que ce que répondit Phedre à Enone, C'est toy qui l'as nommé. <UP></UP>.</P087>
chunks.target_manual: <P068>I perceive, says the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, where you would carry me; you are going to tell me, that if the fix'd Stars are so many Suns, and our Sun the centre of a Vortex that turns round him, why may not every fix'd Star be the centre of a Vortex that turns round the fix'd Star? Our Sun enlightens the Planets; why may not every fix'd Star have Planets to which they give light? You have said it, <UP>I reply'd, and I will not contradict you</UP>.</P068>
source_segments: Ne me trompay-je point, s'écria la Marquise, ou si je vois où vous me voulez mener?
Je n'ay à vous répondre, luy dis-je, que ce que répondit Phedre à Enone, C'est toy qui l'as nommé..
target_segments: I perceive, says the Countess, where you would carry me;
You have said it, I reply'd, and I will not contradict you.
explanations: The original French portrays the Marquise's realization with excitement and a dawning insight: "s'écria" (exclaimed) and "Ne me trompay-je point... ou si je vois" (Am I not mistaken... or do I see). The translation significantly flattens this. "Says the Countess" is a neutral reporting verb, failing to convey the vivacity of "s'écria." Furthermore, "I perceive" is a declarative statement of understanding, which loses the nuance of the Marquise's questioning, active process of deduction. This combined alteration changes the tone, diminishing the Marquise's animated intellectual engagement and the dramatic impact of her realization.

The French text features the philosopher's witty response using a specific literary allusion: "Je n'ay à vous répondre... que ce que répondit Phedre à Enone, C'est toy qui l'as nommé.." (I have nothing to answer you... but what Phaedra answered Oenone, 'It is you who named him/it..'). This quote from Racine's *Phèdre* adds a layer of cultural sophistication, intellectual playfulness, and dramatic resonance, acknowledging the Marquise's perspicacity in an elegant manner typical of Fontenelle's style. The English translation, "You have said it, I reply'd, and I will not contradict you," entirely omits this significant cultural and literary reference, replacing it with a common, direct affirmation. This omission strips the dialogue of its original literary charm and depth, altering the tone of the exchange and manipulating the reader's perception by presenting a less cultured and nuanced interaction than intended by Fontenelle.

chunks.source_manual: <P088>Mais, reprit-elle, voila l'Univers si grand que je m'y perds, je ne sçais plus où je suis, <RW>je ne suis plus rien</RW>. Quoy, tout sera divisé en Tourbillons jettez confusément les uns parmi les autres? Chaque Etoile sera le centre d'un Tourbillon peut-estre aussi grand que celuy où nous sommes? Tout cet espace immense qui comprend nostre Soleil & nos Planetes, ne sera qu'une petite parcelle de l'Univers? Autant d'espaces pareils que d'Etoiles Fixes? <UP></UP>. Cela me confond, me trouble, m'épouvante. Et moy, répondis-je, cela me met à mon aise. Quand le Ciel n'estoit que cette voûte bleuë, où les Etoiles estoient cloüées, l'Univers me paroissoit petit & étroit, je m'y sentois comme oppressé; presentement qu'on a donné infiniment plus d'étenduë & de profondeur à cette voûte <UP></UP>, en la partageant en mille & mille <RW>Tourbillons</RW>, il me semble que je respire avec plus de liberté, & que je suis dans un plus grand air, & asseurement l'Univers a toute une autre magnificence. La Nature n'a rien épargné en le produisant, elle a fait une profusion des richesses qui est tout-à-fait digne d'elle. Rien n'est si beau à se representer que ce nombre prodigieux de Tourbillons, dont le milieu est occupé par un Soleil qui fait tourner des Planetes autour de luy. Les Habitans d'une Planete d'un de ces Tourbillons infinis voyent de tous costez les centres lumineux des Tourbuillons dont ils sont environnez, mais ils n'ont garde d'en voir les Planetes qui n'ayant qu'une lumiere foible, empruntée de leur Soleil, ne la poussent point au delà de leur Monde.<UP></UP>.</P088>
chunks.target_manual: <P069>You have made the Universe so large, says she, that I know not where I am, or what will become of me; what is it all to be divided into heaps confusedly, one among another? Is every Star the centre of a Vortex, as big as ours? Is that vast space which comprehends our Sun and Planets, but an inconsiderable part of the Universe? and are there as many such spaces, as there are fix'd Stars? <UP>I protest it is dreadful. Dreadful, Madam, said I</UP>; I think it very pleasant, when the Heavens were a little blue Arch, stuck with Stars; methought the Universe was too strait and close, I was almost stifled for want of Air; but now it is enlarg'd in heigth and breadth, and a thousand and a thousand Vortex's taken in; I begin to breath with more freedom, and think the Universe to be incomparably <UP>more magnificent than it was before</UP>. Nature hath spar'd no cost, even to profuseness, and nothing can be so glorious, as to see such a prodigious number of Vortex's, whose several centres are possess'd by a particular Sun, which makes the Planets turn round it. The Inhabitants of a Planet of one of these innumerable Vortex's, see on all sides these luminous centres of the Vortex, with which they are encompass'd; but perhaps they do not see the Planets, who receiving but a faint light from their Sun, cannot send it beyond their own World.</P069>

explanations: The French 'je ne suis plus rien' (I am nothing anymore) expresses an existential realization of insignificance. The English translation 'what will become of me' changes this to a more personal concern about her future or fate, subtly altering the philosophical depth of the Marquise's reaction to one of individual apprehension.

The French 'Tourbillons' refers to Descartes' specific cosmological theory of vortices, a key scientific concept. Translating this as 'heaps' discards the scientific term, reduces the complex idea to a shapeless and disordered image, and significantly dumbs down the original text. This is notable as 'Vortex' (the correct equivalent) is used by the translator elsewhere in the same passage.

The French 'peut-estre' (perhaps) conveys the Marquise's speculative and hesitant tone as she considers the new, vast ideas. The English translation omits 'perhaps,' making her question sound more direct and assertive, thereby changing the portrayal of her learning process and intellectual caution.

The French 'Cela me confond, me trouble, m'épouvante' (That confuses me, troubles me, frightens me) describes a nuanced, three-part emotional response. The English 'I protest it is dreadful' simplifies this into a single, stronger term ('dreadful') and adds 'I protest,' lending an uncharacteristic assertiveness and formality to the Marquise's speech, altering her tone.

The English translation adds 'Dreadful, Madam,' to the philosopher's response, making him explicitly acknowledge the Marquise's stated feeling before presenting his contrasting view. The original French 'Et moy, répondis-je, cela me met à mon aise' (And I, I replied, that puts me at ease) is a more direct counterpoint. The addition subtly changes the conversational dynamic, making the philosopher appear more conventionally polite or solicitous.

The French 'infiniment plus d'étenduë & de profondeur' (infinitely more extent and depth) strongly emphasizes the boundless, limitless nature of the new cosmology. The English 'enlarg'd in heigth and breadth' omits 'infiniment' (infinitely), significantly downplaying the radical scale of this expansion and weakening the philosophical impact of the statement about the universe's vastness.

The French phrase 'elle a fait une profusion des richesses qui est tout-à-fait digne d'elle' (she [Nature] has made a profusion of riches which is entirely worthy of her) is a distinct clause praising Nature's munificence. This specific characterization of Nature is effectively omitted in the English target segment, which instead merges elements from the preceding and succeeding French ideas, thereby losing a specific philosophical point about Nature's grandeur.

The French 'Rien n'est si beau à se representer' (Nothing is so beautiful to imagine/picture to oneself) emphasizes the aesthetic quality ('beau') and the internal, imaginative act ('à se representer'). The English 'nothing can be so glorious, as to see' changes 'beautiful' to 'glorious' (a term with grander, potentially more imposing or even reverential connotations) and shifts 'to imagine' to 'to see' (implying direct, external observation rather than mental construction). This alters the nature of the appreciation being expressed from imaginative contemplation to observable majesty.

The French 'Tourbillons infinis' (infinite Vortices) uses 'infinis,' a term loaded with philosophical and cosmological implications of true, boundless infinity. The English 'innumerable Vortex's' (too many to count) is a weaker term that, while conveying great quantity, does not fully capture the profound concept of actual infinity, subtly diminishing the radical scope of the universe Fontenelle describes.

The French phrase 'ils n'ont garde d'en voir les Planetes' (literally 'they take care not to see them,' meaning they certainly do not see them, or are far from seeing them) expresses a strong degree of certainty regarding the invisibility of distant planets. The English translation 'but perhaps they do not see the Planets' introduces 'perhaps,' significantly weakening the philosopher's assertion by adding an element of doubt or epistemic modesty not present in the original French, thus making the scientific claim less definitive.

chunks.source_manual: <P089>Vous m'offrez, dit-elle, une espece de Perspective si longue, que la veuë n'en peut attraper le bout. Je voy clairement les Habitans de la Terre, ensuite vous me faites voir ceux de la Lune & des autres Planetes de nostre Tourbillon assez clairement à la verité, mais moins que ceux de la Terre; apres eux viennent les Habitans des Planetes des autres Tourbillons. Je vous avoüe qu'ils sont tout-à-fait dans l'enfoncement, & que quelque effort que je fasse pour les voir, je ne les apperçois presque point. Et en effet ne sont-ils pas presque aneantis par l'expression dont vous estes obligé de vous servir en parlant d'eux? Il faut que vous les appeliez, les Habitans d'une des Planetes, de l'un de ces Tourbillons infinis? <IIM>Nous mesmes, à qui la mesme expression convient, avoüez que vous ne sçauriez presque plus nous déméler au milieu de tant de Mondes</IIM>. Pour moy, je commence à voir la Terre si effroyablement petite, que je ne croy pas avoir desormais d'empressement pour aucune chose. <IIM>Asseurément, si on a tant d'ardeur de s'agrandir, si on fait desseins sur desseins, si on se donne tant de peine, c'est que l'on ne connoist pas les Tourbillons</IIM>. <UP></UP>. Je pretends bien que ma paresse profite de mes nouvelles lumieres, & quand on me reprochera mon indolence, je répondray: Ah! si vous sçaviez ce que c'est que les Etoiles Fixes! Il faut qu'Alexandre ne l'ait pas sceu, repliquay-je, car un certain Auteur qui tient que la Lune est habitée, dit fort serieusement qu'il n'estoit pas possible qu'Aristote ne fust dans une opinion si raisonnable (comment une verité eust-elle échappé à Aristote?) <UP></UP> mais qu'il n'en voulut jamais rien dire, de peur de déplaire, à Alexandre, qui eust esté au despoir de voir un Monde qu'il n'eust pas pû conquerir. A plus forte raison luy eust-on fait mystere des Tourbillons, des Etoiles Fixes, quand on les eust connus en ce temps-là; c'eust esté faire trop mal sa Cour que de luy en parler. Pour moy qui les connois, je suis bien fâché de ne pouvoir tirer d'utilité de la connoissance que j'en ay. Ils ne guerissent tout au plus, selon vostre raisonnement, que de l'ambition & de l'inquietude, & je n'ay point ces maladies-là. Un peu de foiblesse pour ce qui est beau, voila mon mal, & je ne croy pas que les Tourbillons y puissent rien. Les autres Mondes vous rendent celuy-cy petit, mais ils ne vous gâtent point de beaux yeux, ou une belle bouche, cela vaut toûjours son prix en dépit de tous les Mondes possibles.</P089>
chunks.target_manual: <P070>You present me with a kind of Perspective of so vast a length, that no Eye can reach to the end of it: I plainly see the Inhabitants of the Earth, and you have made me discover those that dwell in the Moon, and in other Planets of our Vortex; but these indeed I do not see so clearly as those of the Earth; after these, we come to the Inhabitants of the Planets which are in other Vortex's, but they are sunk into so great a depth, that tho' I do all I can to see them, yet <UP>I must confess</UP> I can hardly perceive 'em; by the expression you use in speaking of 'em, they seem to be almost annihilated; you ought then to call 'em the Inhabitants of one of those innumerable Vortex's: We our selves, for whom the same expression serves, must confess, that we scarce know where we are, in the midst of so many Worlds; for my own part, I begin to see the Earth so fearfully little, that I believe from henceforth, I shall never be concern'd at all for any thing: That we so eagerly desire to make our selves great, that we are always designing, always troubling and harassing our selves, is certainly because we are ignorant what these Vortex's are; but now I hope my new lights will in part justifie my laziness, and when any one reproaches me with my carelessness, I will answer, Ah did you but know what the fix'd Stars are! It was not fit, said I, that Alexander should know what they were; for a certain Author who maintains that the Moon is inhabited, very gravely tells us, that Aristotle, (from whom no truth could be long conceal'd) must necessarily be of an opinion, back'd with so much reason; but yet he would never acquaint Alexander with the secret, fearing he might run mad with despair, when he knew there was another World, which he could not conquer; with much more reason then was this mystery of Vortex's, and fix'd Stars kept secret in Alexander's time; for tho' they had been known in those days, yet a Man would have been a great Fool, to have said any thing of 'em to Alexander; it had been but an ill way of making his court to that ambitious Prince; for my part, I that know 'em, am not a little troubled to find my self not one jot the wiser for all the knowledge I have of 'em; the most they can do, according to your way of reasoning, is but to cure People of their ambition, and their unquiet restless humour, which are diseases I am not at all troubled with; I confess, I am guilty of so much weakness, as to be in love with what is beautiful; that's my distemper, and I am confident, the Vortex's can never cure it: what if the other Worlds render ours so very little? they cannot spoil fine Eyes, or a pretty Mouth; their value is still the same, in spite of all the Worlds that can possibly exist.</P070>

explanations: The change from "infinis" (infinite) to "innumerable" subtly lessens the philosophical implication of an unbounded, truly infinite universe, a radical idea at the time. "Innumerable" merely suggests a quantity too large to count, whereas "infinite" addresses the fundamental nature and boundless extent of the cosmos.

The original French "vous ne sçauriez presque plus nous déméler" (you would hardly be able to distinguish us anymore) highlights the diminishing discernibility of humanity within the vast cosmos. The translation "we scarce know where we are" shifts this to a sense of human disorientation and being lost, altering the specific philosophical point about humanity's perceived significance.

The French "empressement" signifies a loss of eagerness, zeal, or keen desire. The English translation "shall never be concern'd at all for any thing" suggests a broader and more passive apathy or a complete lack of care or worry, which is a more encompassing emotional state than the original's focus on diminished active pursuit or enthusiasm.

The French "se donne tant de peine" means to give oneself so much trouble or to take great pains. The translation "always troubling and harassing our selves" intensifies this by adding "harassing," which carries a stronger connotation of self-inflicted torment and persistent annoyance not explicitly present in the original "peine" (trouble/effort).

The French "Je pretends bien" expresses a strong intention or expectation ("I fully intend/expect"). Translating this as "I hope" significantly weakens the Marquise's stated resolve. Additionally, changing "que ma paresse profite" (that my laziness profits/benefits from) to "justifie my laziness" shifts the meaning from a practical (albeit humorously framed) gain to a moral or intellectual justification.

The French "mon indolence" refers to a state of habitual laziness or a love of ease. The translation "my carelessness" changes the nature of the trait, suggesting negligence or a lack of attention rather than a deliberate inclination towards inactivity.

The French "Il faut qu'Alexandre ne l'ait pas sceu" functions as a logical deduction meaning "Alexander must not have known it." The translation "It was not fit, said I, that Alexander should know" transforms this inference about Alexander's probable state of knowledge into a moral or propriety-based judgment about what he *should* have known, thus altering the philosopher's reasoning.

The original French "c'eust esté faire trop mal sa Cour que de luy en parler" means "it would have been paying one's court very badly to speak to him of it," focusing on the imprudence and negative diplomatic outcome. The translation renders this as "it had been but an ill way of making his court," but prefaces it with the clause "yet a Man would have been a great Fool," which introduces a strong, somewhat colloquial judgment on an individual's intelligence, an addition not present in the more nuanced French.

The French phrase "tirer d'utilité" means to derive usefulness or benefit, a broad concept. The translation "not one jot the wiser" narrows this potential benefit specifically to a lack of increased wisdom, thereby omitting other forms of utility (e.g., practical application, emotional comfort, or other advantages) that the philosopher might have hoped to gain from his knowledge.

The French term "l'inquietude" translates to restlessness, anxiety, or worry. The English rendering "their unquiet restless humour" is somewhat redundant ("unquiet restless") and the inclusion of "humour" could evoke the archaic medical theory of temperaments (the four humours), thereby adding a layer of specific, potentially anachronistic meaning or quaintness not necessarily intended by the more general French term.

The original French "Un peu de foiblesse pour ce qui est beau, voila mon mal" (A little weakness for what is beautiful, that's my ailment) is a modest and somewhat light self-description. The translation "I confess, I am guilty of so much weakness, as to be in love with what is beautiful; that's my distemper" significantly dramatizes and intensifies this by adding "I confess, I am guilty," escalating "a little weakness" to the passionate state of "being in love," and using the stronger "distemper" for "mal." This changes the philosopher's tone from mild self-awareness to a more theatrical or serious admission.

The French "mais ils ne vous gâtent point de beaux yeux, ou une belle bouche" implies that the existence of other worlds does not spoil *for you* (the perceiver) the appreciation or pleasure derived from beautiful features. The English translation "they cannot spoil fine Eyes, or a pretty Mouth" shifts the focus to an objective statement that these features themselves cannot be physically spoiled or ruined by the other worlds, thereby losing the subjective nuance of the original, which pertains to the perceiver's experience and valuation.

The original French "l'expression dont vous estes obligé de vous servir" (the expression which you are obliged/compelled to use) implies a necessity or constraint on the philosopher's choice of words when discussing inhabitants of distant worlds. The translation "the expression you use" omits this crucial sense of obligation, making the philosopher's diminishing language seem like a voluntary choice rather than an unavoidable consequence of the vast scale being described. This subtly shifts the reader's perception of the philosopher's agency and the nature of scientific description.

chunks.source_manual: <P090>C'est une étrange chose que l'Amour, répondit-elle en riant; il se sauve de tout, & il n'y a point de Systême qui luy puisse faire de mal. Mais aussi parlez-moy franchement, vostre Systême est-il bien vray? Ne me déguisez rien, je vous garderay le secret. Il me semble qu'il n'est appuyé que sur une petite convenance bien legere. Une Etoile Fixe & lumineuse d'elle-mesme comme le Soleil, par consequent il faut qu'elle soit comme le Soleil, le centre & l'ame d'un Monde, & qu'elle ait ses Planetes qui tournent autour d'elle. Cela est-il d'une necessité bien absoluë? Ecoutez, Madame, répondis-je, puis que nous sommes en humeur de mêler toûjours des folies de galanterie à nos Discours les plus serieux, les raisonnemens de Mathematique sont faits comme l'Amour. Vous ne sçauriez accorder si peu de chose à un Amant, que bien-tost aprés il ne faille luy en accorder davantage, & puis encore davantage, & à la fin cela va loin. De mesme accordez à un Mathematicien le moindre principe, il va vous en tirer une consequence, qu'il faudra que vous luy accordiez aussi, & de cette consequence encore une autre, & malgré vous-mesme il vous mene si loin, qu'à peine le pouvez-vous croire. Ces deux sortes de Gens-là prennent toûjours plus qu'on ne leur donne. Vous convenez que quand deux choses sont semblables en tout ce qui me paroist, je les puis croire aussi semblables en ce qui ne me paroist point, s'il n'y a rien d'ailleurs qui m'en empesche. De là j'ay tiré que la Lune estoit habitée, parce qu'elle ressemble à la Terre, les autres Planetes, parce qu'elles ressemblent à la Lune. Je trouve que les Etoiles Fixes ressemblent à nostre Soleil, je leur attribuë tout ce qu'il a. Vous estes engagée trop avant pour pouvoir reculer, il faut franchir le pas de bonne grace. Mais, dit-elle, sur le pied de cette ressemblance que vous mettez entre les Etoiles Fixes & nostre Soleil, il faut que les Gens d'un autre grand Tourbillon ne le voyent que comme une petite Etoile Fixe, qui se montre à eux seulement pendant leurs nuits.</P090> <P091>Cela est hors de doute, répondis-je. Nostre Soleil est si proche de nous en comparaison des Soleils des autres Tourbillons, que sa lumiere doit avoir infiniment plus de force sur nos yeux que la leur. Nous ne voyons donc que luy quand nous le voyons, & il efface tout; mais dans un autre grand Tourbillon c'est un autre Soleil qui y domine, & il efface à son tour le nostre, qui n'y paroist que pendant les nuits avec le reste des autres Soleils étrangers, c'est à dire, des Etoiles Fixes. On l'attache avec elles à cette grande voûte du Ciel, & il y fait partie de quelque Ourse, ou de quelque Taureau. Pour les Planetes qui tournent autour de luy, <NCP>nostre Terre, par exemple</NCP>, comme on ne les voit point de si loin, on n'y songe seulement pas. Ainsi tous les Soleils, sont Soleils de jour pour le Tourbillon où ils sont placez, & Soleils de nuit pour tous les autres Tourbillons. Dans leur Monde, ils sont les uniques de leur espece, par tout ailleurs ils ne servent qu'à faire nombre. Ne faut-il pas pourtant, reprit-elle, que les Mondes, malgré cette égalité different en mille choses, car un fond de ressemblance ne laisse de porter des differences infinies?</P091>
chunks.target_manual: <P071>This Love, reply'd the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, smiling, is a strange thing; let the World go how 'twill, 'tis never in danger; there is no System can do it any harm. But tell me freely, is your System true? Pray conceal nothing from me; I will keep your secret very faithfully; it seems to have for its foundation, but a slight probability; which is, that if a fix'd Star be in it self a luminous Body, like the Sun, then by consequence, it must as the Sun is, be the Centre and Soul of a World; and have its Planets turning round about it: But is there an absolute necessity it must be so? Madam, said I, since we are in the humour of mingling amorous Follies with our most serious Discourses, I must tell you, that in Love and the Mathematicks People reason alike: Allow never so little to a Lover, yet presently after you must grant him more; nay more and more, which will at last go a great way: In like manner, grant but a Mathematician one little Principle, he immediately draws a consequence from it, to which you must necessarily assent; and from this consequence another, till he leads you so far (whether you will or no) that you have much ado to believe him. These two sorts of People, Lovers and Mathematicians, will always take more than you give 'em. You grant that when two things are like one another in all those things that appear to you, it is possible they may be like one another in those things that are not visible, if you have not some good reason to believe otherwise: Now this way of arguing have I made use of. The Moon, say I, is inhabited, because she is like the Earth; and the other Planets are inhabited, because they are like the Moon; I find the fix'd Stars to be like our Sun, therefore I attribute to them what is proper to that: You are now gone too far to be able to retreat, therefore you must go forward with a good grace. But, says the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, if you build upon this resemblance or likeness which is between our Sun and the fix'd Stars, then, to the People of another great Vortex, our Sun must appear no bigger than a small fix'd Star, and can be seen only when 'tis Night with them. <UP>Without doubt</UP>, Madam, said I, it must be so: Our Sun is much nearer to us, than the Suns of other Vortex's, and therefore its Light makes a much greater impression on our Eyes, than theirs do: We see nothing but the light of our own Sun, and when we see that, it darkens and hinders us from seeing any other light: but in another great Vortex, there is another Sun, which rules and governs, and, in its turn, extinguisheth the light of our Sun, which is never seen there, but in the Night, with the rest of the other Suns, that is the fix'd Stars; with them our Sun is fastned to the great arched roof of Heaven, where it makes a part of some Bear or Bull: For the Planets which turn round about it, <NCP>(our Earth for Example)</NCP> as they are not seen at so vast a distance, so no body doth so much as dream of 'em: All the Suns then are Day Suns in their own Vortex's, but Night Suns in other Vortex's: In his own World or Sphere every Sun is single, and there is but one to be seen; but every where else, they serve only to make a number. May not the Worlds, reply'd the <IIM>Countess</IIM>, notwithstanding this great resemblance between 'em, differ in a thousand other things; for tho' they may be alike in one particular, they may differ infinitely in others.</P071>

s'il n'y a rien d'ailleurs qui m'en empesche.

un autre Soleil qui y domine
